title: This was a hit
text: Got this as a gift for my friend’s daughter, she loved it, she is 3 and plays with every morning before going to her play school..

title: Mom of FOUR BOYS says... BUY THIS TOY
text: I have often said I would pay double if not triple the expense as long as it was a toy that is PLAYED with and is DURABLE.  This toy is it!!!  I have 4 boys ages (8, 6.5, 4.5, 3).  All of them LOVE this toy.  Even I like playing with it!  They fit together easily.  They have been thrown around and not one of them has broken.  They are educational in the geometry and spatial reasoning and building skills.  Perfect!!!  Bite the bullet, yes I know they are a little pricey, and buy them.  You won't be disappointed!

title: Five Star Toy at A Rip Off Price
text:
I love these tiles and ordered a set of 100 last year. The kids love them so much (2 to 12 yrs) that I decided to get a second set. Just paid $110 delivered from Module R. This company wants almost twice that much for the same tiles.

Normally I don't downgrade an item for the cost but if I had given the product five stars, the alert would have been lost.

Check the manufacturer's website for other alternatives to purchase.

Addendum: The price has come down since I first posted this review. Although it might seem high, you'll find the durability, educational value, and fun for all ages make it worth the investment. I'm going to order another set for the fifth grandchild.

title: 100% Fan of Magna-Tiles
text:
My boy was two when we got the Magna-Tiles. Instantly a hit, he rushes to play with them.

Easy to use, they lock into place, making these excellent for not-quite-coordinated hands.

In filling out the questionnaire before writing this review, Amazon asks for 1-5 stars about a few things, just as they do for any toy review. I gave each five stars:

How much fun is this toy? Tons. My toddler can't get enough of it. I enjoy building with him.

How would you rate this toy's educational value? He can organize them by color and shape, and thinks now like a little architect.

How durable is this toy? Nothing has broken yet despite full body contact playing.

How do you rate this toy overall? An enthusiastic five stars. My toddler's one regret is that there are only 100 tiles. He's like hundreds more.

Buy the set of 100. You'll need that many to get anything done. It will be worth every penny.

Anthony Trendl
TreeFortBooks.com

title: Best toy ever for creative play
text: My son (age 3) loves this toy. We enjoy watching him create towers, castles and much more. This has been the BEST toy that we've purchased thus far.

title: Excellent toy, well worth it
text: These have been a huge hit at my house!!  Everyone who has come over has loved them, they are so much fun and my kids have used them to make so many different things.  The only problem is that I have to hide them when my nephew comes over as he just fights with my 4 year old over them lol!  Cannot recommend enough.  They are good quality, and even though they are pricey I know these will stand the test of time, as is not the case with so many toys that we own.  Can't wait to add to our collection!

title: Expensive, but worth it.
text: These tiles are amazing. Fun, durable, easy for the kids to put together in a variety of ways -- even fun to clean up! They *will* occasionally come crashing down on each other which can be hard for the little ones to deal with, but that's a lesson too -- and an important one to learn, so we're working on it in our house. I think I enjoy playing with these as much as my kids. ** I first saw these at my kids' preschool where they have been played with a LOT and are still in wonderful working order. They are definitely durable.

title: My class loves these building pieces - I have several ...
text: My class loves these building pieces - I have several sets!  If you are buying more, please buy the same brand - there are several types out there.

title: Best Toy for Chldren Ever - Invest in Them
text: This is one of the best toys ever invented. I've bought so many sets (the 100 set is an essential starter kits) for children, I should be their spokesperson. But, really, girls, boys, and ADULTs  will enjoy this beautifully made set of magnetic building tiles in beautiful translucent colors. They are expensive and the price keeps going up but DON"T be taken in my imitators. Magnatile magnets are strong and can be built up and up. I like to get a couple of sets at a time and then add to them for special children or families every year ( the more you have, the greater buildings can be constructed). I've never recommended this toy to anyone, who didn't end up loving it as much as I do. Spent the money: it's a worthy investment and will keep children busy for hours, creating and using their imagination and inventiveness to create new designs. My daughter with four kids probably has about eight sets and the neighbor's kids would knock on their door to ask to play with them. Equally loved by girls and boys. I keep a few sets at my house for my children visitors (and love to watch their parents also start playing with them). I can attest they last forever and are so easy to clean up, being magnetic and off several sizes: they fit back into their boxes easily. Spend the money, you won't regret it.

title: Well worth the money.
text:
While looking for Christmas gift ideas this fall for our 3 and 5 year old boy and girl, I came across Magna Tiles. Didn't know anyone who had them, but the reviews on Amazon and across the web are outstanding. The price tag was high, but we have so many toys in this house that nobody plays with that I wanted to buy one big, quality item that I thought maybe would keep their attention.

Magna Tiles definitely fit the bill. Since we got them at Christmas, they are played with twice a week, and probably would be played with more if they weren't in a closet. Our 5 yr old girl makes intricate designs, and our 3 yr old boy does simpler ones but still has caught on very quickly. They play well together and if they need to they will divide all the pieces up so there is no fighting. Many times it is a group effort though. Right now they are making houses for their Zhu Zhu Puppies.

These are also very durable toys. None have been broken yet and I don't see it happening. We have a 9 month old puppy and he has no interest in chewing these because they are too hard for him to pick up, which is a bonus. If you are looking for a nice quality item that the whole family will play with and kids will enjoy together, Magna Tiles are great. There is a little learning curve at first while the children learn how to work them and how to work the magnets, but they will be learning how to build intricate designs with all the triangles included in no time!

Edit 11/2014. These are still a hit! Kids are almost 7 & 9 now. One kiddo that comes over wants to play with these the entire time!

title: Great toy
text: Love these. Can't say enough good things about them. Got my seven year old these for Christmas and it's one of his favorite gifts. Great for imagination play. Was torn between these and the cheaper brand but I am happy I opted for these as they seem well made for play. Would recommend.

title: wow!
text:
Okay, this is an expensive toy. Especially since many pieces are needed to really enjoy it. I'd say that 100 pieces are pretty much a minimum to get started and that's over $100.
However, this toy has wonderful play value or many ages, genders and personalities. Our 3yr old grandson and 30 yr old son-in-law were both entranced.
So though this toy is terrific and probably a good value for the amount of play and creativity it will inspire I didn't give it 5 stars since it's out of the price range for many families.

title: Best Magnetic Tiles!
text: I bought these for my son's third birthday, but I also have another son who is almost five. Both my boys love these Magna-Tiles. This 100-piece set has enough tiles for both of them to play and create whatever they want. They mostly create buildings and space ships, but it provides hours of fun. The tiles have pretty strong magnets and we have had no issues with building up. They have also been dropped quite a bit and no cracks in the plastic, as of yet. The box they come in is very precise as to where the pieces go so they all fit, so I purchased a separate storage bin for quicker clean up. I would absolutely recommend this product to friends and family and will most likely be buying additional tile sets from Magna-Tiles. We love them!

title: We LOVE our Magna-tiles!
text: My four children (ages 5, twin 3 1/2 year olds and a 2 year old) love our magna-tiles. We recieved a 30 piece set of the solid ones for my sons 4th birthday and we needed more as the kids got older and our inventions got bigger. We got the large set for Christmas & I must admit, I was so anxious for Christmas morning to come so that my kids could open them and I could play with them. It's been nearly four months and my kids and I still play with them every single day. I am always amazed by the concoctions they come up with. I prefer the clear tiles over the solids, they just add more visual interest to our creations. I love the magna-tiles because they are fun, educational, durable and we get so much quality time out of creating things together as a family. They are well worth every penny. I would add that my two year old is on the young end for this toy, she gets more joy out of demolition than invention, so we really have to watch her with them. I would recommend these for ages 3 and up. These are one toy that you will never outgrow!

text:
you are probably a parent (or teacher) if you are looking at this toy, and you probably have experienced dozens if not more times that you've bought something for your kids that got little to no play. i know this because i am one of them!

well this was a gift to my 3 1/2 year old son for christmas. he has a 5 1/2 year old brother. let me tell you that this was THE HIT of christmas day, and we are talking about competing gifts like a VERY expensive star wars lego set for the older son.

i don't know what it is about them - they are easy to use, stick together so well and make amazing 3D creations. it's been a month since christmas and they are still playing with them EVERY DAY. they are so great that we will probably add the DX kit which has a set of wheels and a few pieces with windows/doors.

they are not cheap however if you rate toys by $/hr played, the magna tiles have been one of the best toys we have had!

title: Best and longest lasting toy so far
text: One of the best building toys today. Practically indestructible (I saw one in the street one day that had been run over by cars, brought it home and it still worked). No boundaries on imaginative play. Fantastic way to learn about how different geometric shapes can be used together. Initial set really needs more pieces, so bought this as the starter set for another child. Unlike Legos, this can be used endlessly -- as young as 2, as old as 10 or 12 (but they might want a second set to build higher / bigger). A large base plate can be purchased separately, that's the only useful option other than more pieces.

title: Worth the investment; hours of creative, spatial learning
text: So, so expensive, but so, so worth it. They had these at my daughter's preschool and at a hands-on-museum we went to (on a light up table, even more fun!) We got her a set of 32 blocks for her 2nd birthday. Last year for Christmas we added this 100-piece set, so now we have enough to build some AMAZING things. Both my daughter (4) and son (2) LOVE these. They are virtually indestructible and so great for creative play and encouraging spatial learning. They play with these for hours at a stretch. You wouldn't believe some of the things they build with these. Well worth the investment; I can see these being the kind of toy I keep around til I have grandchildren!

title: Awesome

title: Magna-Tiles for the win!
text:
Magna-Tiles are awesome. I first encountered them at a Children's Museum and was so impressed with them. I work with toddlers, and magnets are typically a no-go for them, but these are made so well that they are safe for littles to play with!

I bought this set for my twin nephews when they turned 3. I see magna-tiles similar to Lego- the usage only gets better and more elaborate as kids get older. They are now almost 5 and still love playing with them. The tiles have held up well and I continue to add to their set.

Magna-Tiles are a great option if you're looking for toys that don't have music, lights, or one set purpose. I like that kids get to be creative and decide how they are going to use them, instead of being told by the toy what its function is. There are so few toys left like this these days! I've never known anyone who uses or plays with them to be disappointed. Very cool idea, well made and executed, and they hold up over time! (I've always stuck with the name brand and not used the knock off.)

title: Best kind out there
text:
These are expensive, but they are the best out there. Unlike going from duplos
to legos, I’ve found my kids have loved these for years.

title: Start with 100, add 48 and 32 plus expansions
text:
Our family (and extended family and close friends) all swear by Magna-Tiles. I first became familiar with them when my best friend's kids asked for them for one birthday and then asked for MORE tiles the following year so they wouldn't fight over them. I didn't see them in person until my son started preschool and they had them there. I couldn't understand what all the fuss was about until I actually used them.

I started out with the 100 piece set and we loved it. I also bought this 32-piece set for travel and quickly realized that it wasn't really enough pieces to do much. The [[ASIN:B0093LSWIE Magna-Tiles 12148 Clear Colors 48 pc DX set Toy]] is also only good as an expansion pack as are the ACTUAL expansion packs.

I found everything much cheaper on Jet.com as there aren't very frequent sales on this item. I've never tried the knockoff brands.

The pieces are REALLY sturdy even with a destructive 20-month-old. He is not above throwing them at the wall pretty hard. We haven't had any problems despite that. I prefer the clear pieces to the solid ones if you're going for aesthetics. Are they pricey? Ridiculously so but they stick to each other well and I think they will last a really long time.

Surprisingly, the 100 pc set makes the best travel set. Because of the odd pieces in the 48 pc, the box is much longer and bigger. And the 32 pc set isn't really great as anything more than an expansion set.

text: My grandsons Love this product.  It exercises their mind and motor skills.  It fosters creativity and utilizes fine motor skills.  I will likely purchase more.

title: LOVE THEM (AND CHILD DOES TOO)
text: I got these for my 4 yr old girl's birthday.  I knew *I* would like them; I always like building things.  I hesitated, though, because they are supposed to be for daughter not me, and because they are super-expensive, and my daughter usually has only moderate interest in construction-type toys, like lego and bricks; I am usually more interested in building than she is.  But these tiles are wonderful, and we both love them equally.  When we first opened them and started building, she said she wanted to build all night long.  She is very interested in tiny figures (little dogs, Playmobil and Polly Pocket figures); and with Magna tiles, one can make an amazing colorful palace, in which each tiny figure can have his or her own apartment.  Love it!  The translucent set is definitely the way to go, because then the little figures can look out of their colorful windows, and be seen from outside.  I can also see that this toy will grow with her, there are lots of ways to play with it.  Great toy!  -- I would actually recommend it to anybody thinking of buying a castle or palace for a child.  This does a lot of the same goodness, and then some.

title: Christmas day hit for niece and nephew!!
text: I work at an elementary school day care and I was familiar with the product. My school children, age 5-10, love to build with these tiles and their creations are never ending. The geometry of the tiles promote this creativity. I definitely recommend the clear tiles so they can see through the buildings. Half of the fun of playing with the tiles is building...the other half is knocking it down. The product is so well built (my school set is over 7 years old) I've never had a tile crack or break. The magnets make clean-up a cinch. Get them close together and they pick up themselves!

title: my son LOVES this
text:
While I have yet to open this package - it's a Christmas gift for my son, I do know how much he loves these tiles. This is one of the toys they have available in his pre-school/daycare class and he absolutely loves building with these- so much so that his teachers had to limit his acccess to them so the other kids could have a shot at them. He is a very enthusiastic builder with these tiles building everything from garages to airplanes (he's 4)and all sorts of things in between. The magnets are fully encased within the tiles so I don't have much concern about them breaking loose or posing any type of hazard. His teachers strongly endorsed the learning potential for this learning toy- mathmetical, spacial relations, all the way down to the basics of color and shape recognition.
The only drawback to this toy is the price - it is steep for those on a budget so the grandparents helped chip in on it especially after they saw how engrossed he was playing with these tiles at school. IF they were more affordable I would consider buying some of the other sets I've seeen here on Amazon as I was unable to find them at any of the local retailers ro include the major national chains.

My husband has tried to "find the magic" in these and is not impressed.  Really disappointed for the price. Will be returning.

title: Not worth the price amymore.
text:
My kids received 2 sets of Magna-tiles for Christmas. We went with Magna-tiles because most of the reviews stated that they had the strongest magnets, and because of that were worth the price. When we opened the box i was surprised at how not strong those magnets were! And then my 9 year old spend a very frustrating hour trying to build that robot pictured on the example paper and couldn't.... Then I spent half an hour trying to do the same and couldn't... I am an engineer and my opinion is that the magnets are not strong enough to hold the weight of that structure. Maybe earlier when those magnets were stronger... So I went online and started researching it a little more. I came across more recent reviews that state that the magnets indeed got weaker in Magna-tiles. I sent an email to customer service and the answer basically was that the magnets are adequate, they do what they need to do and the robot takes practice. Ok then. I am giving it 3 stars because it is still a good toy but given weaker magnets, very limited shapes and high cost it is simply not worth the higher price anymore. There are other similar toys out there now that are superior to this one.

Update: just took a star away because anything other than 4-6-8 sided prisms collapses. We tried to build a couple of stuctures kids build using playmags and can't: the magnets of the new magna-tiles aren't strong enough. Very disapointing!

title: Definitely Buy This
text: I read quite a few reviews before I decided to purchase this item.  This was a great gift for my four-year-old granddaughter.  We made a house for her pet cats (stuffed) and aquariums for their house.  This is a very enjoyable product and the only negative feature I would list is there were not enough tiles.  Guess I should have purchased two of the 100 piece sets!!!  One thing I did not see mentioned is they are fun to clean up.  The pieces attach to each other and it is almost a game in itself to pick them up.  I highly recommend Magna-Tiles to anyone looking for a great gift.

title: Best value for fun!

title: Favorite kids toy
text: My toddler easily is able to build with magnatiles without frustration. He will play with them for hours.

title: Fun, durable, and entertaining toy for all ages!!
text:
You know a toy is pretty special if it can withstand the pounding of little hands at a daycare. I was intrigued when I saw these at multiple daycare centers I visited. Every day that I would pick up my son, he was playing with them, and I wanted to get a set for home, but they were so darn expensive!

So we got some cheaper knock offs. No. No. No. This is one situation where cheaper just won't do. The tiles didn't line up as well, they didn't stick together as well, and just did not have the same durability. Well, four years later, I have more children, and I keep wanting to get them, so I finally do.

I wish I had gotten them sooner. My 2 year old twins love stacking them, and the magnets are so good that it facilitates building even by clumsy toddler hands. The tiles are so durable that they have survived beautifully after being thrown down stairs, on tile, at windows, and at siblings. My twins' favorite thing to do is build a tall tower then run into it, causing the tiles to crash. Not a single scratch, chip, or other sign of wear and tear is to be seen.

I am such a fan of these tiles that I now have 2 sets for my kids. I know that they will be enjoyed for many more years to come, and my husband and I enjoy building with them as well. I even bought a set for my nieces, and now that family is a big fan as well. It is truly worth the investment.

title: versatile and colorful
text: Our child started playing with these immediately.  They keep his attention, and he plays with them for a while each day.  He likes them so much that he has requested more.  He has already started combining them with other toys, e.g. making garages for his toy vehicles.  He also sticks them to the refrigerator.  The tiles are very colorful as advertised, and are sturdy enough that they can be dropped on the floor without breaking.  Our child is only 4 years old, but can make medium-size structures without help.  If we had it to do over, we would purchase these again.

title: The more the better!
text: These magnetized tiles are colorful, easy for little ones to maneuver into place, and great for building to allow their creative juices to flow.

title: Great quality/ nice beginner set for collection
text:
These tiles are built with high grade plastic. I have several sets and have never had a broken tile. My kids have put them through smashing towers, stepping on tiles and even throwing them. While they are pricey, they are built to last.

Also makes for a great collection. There are many different sets, shapes, colors (glow in the dark even) and figurines you can purchase to build with.

title: Fun For the Whole Family
text:
I was first introduced to Magna-Tiles in my daughter's pre-K classroom. A group of children were huddled around a table creating all kinds of buildings with these flat plastic tiles

There are two options on the quantities: 32 piece or 100 piece. I feel this is an expensive toy, but the 100 piece box Is worth the splurge. You can make more elaborate structures with 100 pieces, and, if you have two children, you will be able to split the tiles and they will both be able to make decent creations with minimal fighting over the tiles.

In the 100 piece pack you will receive 4 large squares, 50 small squares, 11 right triangles, 20 equilateral triangles, and 15 isosceles triangles

There are 5 colors used in the set: blue, yellow, red, purple, and green Each tile has one or two (depending on length) strong magnets embedded in the side to allow the pieces to stick together

My children can split these tiles and play for hours. They have been known to build roads on which to drive their cars, elaborate garages to store their cars, beds for their princesses to sleep on, and towers to see how high they can go before the pieces come tumbling down. We’ve had these tiles for five years and the children still play with them.

This is a fun addition to the building toys (legos, duplos, wooden blocks) we already have. I really like how the magnets help the tiles snap together. This is a five-star toy and the entire family enjoys playing with it.

title: Detrimental quality control
text: Recently I bought a brand new box directly from the company. I was flabbergasted with quality or lack of thereof which was evident based on the photos I took and send as proof of how the product was presented. I immediately contacted them, and they offered to replace or refund me minus the S&H costs. This is the first time I experienced something like this: a company expecting the customer to pay for the S&H costs of a faulty product. My disappointment is unmeasurable with this brand: product and customer service.

title: Extremely Disappointing - Terrible Quality
text:
We are a Montessori/Waldorf family and favor well designed, open-ended creative toys. So I was VERY excited to purchase magna tiles to add to our play. I waited a long time to buy them as they are an expensive toy and I wanted to introduce them at a good age. I have a 3 year old that I thought was ready for these.

Magna tiles are the brand that everyone says is the best quality. They’re also the highest priced.

These were EXTREMELY disappointing. First of all, any toy that is in the over $100 range should at least be of a solid construction, quality and usability. The magnets don’t line up, the negative sides don’t connect properly (even though this brand says that they do) and any constructions immediately collapse or topple. They are not sturdy at all. I was extremely frustrated after 5 minutes of use. My 3 year old can/will build flat structures (that’s the only way they work properly) but the price point is supposed to support 3D building. It doesn’t.

I’m baffled as to why this brand receives so many accolades. It’s a terrible quality for the price point. I also bought an expansion and I’m planning to send both this one and the expansion back. I’ve spent $135 for a pile of flimsy plastic that you can’t even use to construct anything worth playing with!

My grandson let his thoughts be known about this by promptly knocking over anything they were about 75% finished with.  The tiles are great for those who love to construct and my grandson loves to sit by himself and put things together.  Although I do think he has just as much fun knocking over things others put together.

title: Probably the best toy ever invented
text: I purchased this toy after seeing how much my then 2 year old loved playing with it at his daycare. Quite easily the BEST TOY PURCHASE EVER MADE!!! It really enabled a child to build whatever their imagination allows. Since it's purchase over two years ago, my older son (now 5) plays with it everyday. Also my younger son has been playing with it since he was 18 months old. Together they play with it every day for hours building "garages" or "racetracks" for their hot wheels toys, "castles" with their little green soldiers, "spaceships", etc... You can use them to also "teach" colors. We shine a flashlight and place two clear color tiles to see what color they make. Kids love to build them and place a lantern in them to see it glow in the dark when lights go off. We take it everywhere for vacation. When family and friends come over it's the first toy that gets pulled out. Our nephews and neighbors in age from 3-13 years old. They all love it also. It's a pricey present but guaranteed to entertain and educate for years. Best toy purchase bar none. It wins over all the fads every time!!!! Invest in a clear box to store. title: popular with many ages 3 through adult.  I would buy again.
text: I purchased the 100 tile set and divided it into two sets of 50 tiles.  This was more economical than buying two smaller sets.  I have one set at home for our grandchildren and took the others to church to use with 4 and five year olds (an experiment in a situation with 20+ children).  I gave only four stars because they are expensive and I don't know how durable they are, having just bought them.  I will look at this again in about 6 months?  Our 4 year old grandchild really likes to play with them, but so does her mother and other adults as well (including the teens at church).  They are not as easy to put together as one might think.  The tiles will stack vertically, but the magnets are not strong enough to hold a piece in a horizontal mode, without support underneath.  This is not a complaint, just a fact! However, they are fun and a challenge!  I would buy these again, though the cost is a factor.  Hopefully they will last a long time.  I put a lot of faith in reviews and these were well reviewed.

title: Weak seams, thin plastic
text: We bought these on a sale, so it's too late for us to return them. Don't buy it if you have young kids. These are very poorly made, they have a weak seam holding the sides together, so if you are using them with young kids that aren't super gentle, these will break and the magnets will be able to get out and pose a health hazard. We bought name brand hoping to have the safest option, unfortunately these are the worst of the three brands we tried. I regret wasting the money. Playmags brand are thicker, more durable and better made and much less money. Connetix brand are expensive like these but very nice quality. These magnatiles, are thin plastic that can easily break. It's hard to take a good photo in this light but I even handed a mix of tiles to another adult and said sort out any damaged looking ones and it was all magnatiles in their pile. We only opened the tiles today and are very disappointed. The shapes and everything are fun, they work fine but they look damaged new from box, I can't imagine after actually being in the toys for a while.

title: This toy is an absolute WINNER all around IMO
text:
OK first off, I just had to say that I didn't shell out the big buck$ for this toy the first time around.

I found it at a thrift store...the standard 100 set for five bucks.

Yes, five bucks. I had no idea what I was buying, I just bought it and figured it would be interesting.

That was when my daughter was five. She has that set at granny's and I actually found another set -this time a 100 clear with a 32 piece clear set included for $150 on an auction site (with free ship and no tax) so I shelled out the big bucks for that set to stay at home.

My daughter LOVES these tiles. She saw them at a museum (think it's genius that they have these for kids) -the children just love them and their endless patterns are fascinating to make and beautiful to look at.

She's almost 8 by the way and she still enjoys playing with them. The brilliant colors and the ease of building and collapsing capability make these an all-around winner.

I think that the capability of this toy goes beyond pretend play, as in math skills and such. But I just wanted to add that my kid likes to make play houses and put her My Little Ponies in them too.

Best yet, they "hold" their value....they can be resold at e-auctions for pretty darned close to what you paid for them. So don't pay too much. My advice: shop around.

title: Five Stars

title: best purchase for a birthday of a 3 year old girl!
text: All my children love this toy.  At the Preschool my children attend, I was informed this was the number one toy for every age (elementary age and younger) and we enjoy building and designing 3D shapes all-day long.  If you are considering this toy, just buy it, you won't regret it!

title: Love magnatiles!
text: My kids just LOVE magna-tiles.  They have them at their daycare and its always the first thing that they go to when I drop them off.  When I pick them up, they are always throwing a fit about trying to play with them even longer.  I bought these for them for Christmas because I know that they would be perfect.  I looked at the cheaper brands, but they seem to be more flimsy and not as well built.  What I love about these is that they are riveted together and will be hard for them to break. The price is a little steep, but its worth it for the quality of the product.

title: Good for their imagination and well worth the money
text: Grandkids will play for hours with this.  Good for their imagination and well worth the money.

title: Piece of mind for the extra money
text: My 3.5 year old loves building with blocks, legos, lincoln logs, etc. I used to run a daycare and one of the most popular toys at any of the daycares in our district were magnatiles. I saw really cool magnet sets that were half the price online and was tempted to purchase those brands so I could hook her up with more bang for my buck, different shapes or whatever and maybe I will in the future. I purchased these because I knew first hand after watching k-6 grade children beat the heck out of them over years and never had one crack. My 1 year old puts everything in her mouth and my fear is she'll get a magnet in her belly. I bought magnatiles because I feel confident in the construction and sturdiness of this brand that even my little Ruzillah isn't going to be able to break them. Fingers crossed. So far, they have crashed, been bashed, been thrown and it's like they are still fresh out of the package. Both girls love them and I love to build with them too so it's great to spend time together. I'll have to buy a few of the big sets over time to have enough for the cities we want to build but the big set is a good starting point. None of the pieces are small enough for my 1 year old to get down her throat. (I'm holding out on the 3D shapes because of this). Magnets are strong enough, colors are vibrant, and this new rivet feature (new to me) is added safety, or at least it seems so.

title: Excellent toy!

Both the 4 year old and 2 year old can use them although the little one need a lot of help. Great toys that grow imagination, creativity, motor skills and really is just plain fun. Highly recommend!

title: Pre-K teacher
text: I teach pre-k and the children love this toy! I found out about this toy from another teacher who said that the children really enjoy it.  It was a bit expensive but a few parents chipped in for it and when they saw how much the children enjoyed it, they decided to buy it for their homes as well. It is a fun and safe toy. Many magnet toys are not safe for young children but these are big toys (not swallow-able) and the children can build beautiful structures with them! If there are more than three children, I would recommend getting the pack of 100 since children enjoy using many tiles to build structures!

title: Yes, it's worth it
text:
UPDATE 12/2018 - three years and one rambunctious boy later, this was still my best toy purchase ever. Not one tile has broken. NOT ONE. My second child, who was a fetus when I bought this for his sister, plays with them every day and they are as good as new. They have traveled the country, been tossed in bags, still perfect.

Original review - 11/2015:
I had major reservations about spending so much on a toy, but the play value is worth it. Kids and adults enjoy collaborating on castles, corals, houses... Get creative with flashlights to add a little something. These will be around for many years to come. Its been a year and we haven't even broken a tile yet (clumsy family) meaning they are likely indestructible.

title: Magna-Tiles a Must for this Retired Teachers Granddaughter!
text:
This set of Magna-Tiles was purchased as a Christmas gift for my granddaughter who is approaching 3.
They are recommended for 3 year olds and up. She is putting things together and will enjoy them now.
I previously taught preschool and this was a must have for my classroom. Children enjoy constructing with the different shapes and colors. It offers them the opportunity to develop a wide range of skills: ability to build two and three dimensional creations, shape recognition, patterning skills, sorting and stacking, symmetry,eye-hand coordination and creativity among other things.

title: The Best Toy We've Ever Owned
text:
This has been my kids' favorite toy for 2.5 years now. Nothing else even comes close. We bought the 32 pc. starter set when they were 2.5 yrs old, and quickly followed up by buying the 100 pc set. They just turned 5, and we've added two more of the 100 pc sets to their collection. I have BGG triplets and all three love to play with them, and every kid who comes over loves them. As my kids have gotten older, they've learned to build larger and more complex structures, and even use them to interact with other toys (e.g. building castles for figurines or bridges over railroads). I don't see them falling out of use for years to come. I recommend getting the translucent set as the kids like to put figurines and other toys inside their creations and want to be able to see what's inside. I don't recommend the 32 pc set as its difficult to build much with 32 pieces and its simply not a good value.

Pros:
* Durable - We've never broken a piece despite being routinely stepped on, dropped, toppled, and thrown into a storage drawer.
* Excellent play value - Kid's play with them frequently, and for long periods of time (up to 4 hours). The manufacturer recommends age 3+, but they're also great for kids younger than that. The magnets are pretty strong, so they hold structures well, and the kids don't get frustrated by things falling apart.
* Easy to clean up and store - They're flat and magnetic, so they pick up fast, are easy to stack, and don't take up much space. Consequently, they're the first toy my kids pick up when asked to clean their playroom. If you're short on space and looking for a limited number of high-quality toys, this has to be at the top of your list.
* Safe - The magnets are completely enclosed in plastic and can't come out.
* Educational - You'd be surprised what can be made out of them.

Cons:
* Not cheap - Sometimes you just gotta pay for the good stuff. They're still a great value, though.

text:

They are also very sturdy and have held up to being walked on many times.

My two grandsons, ages 3.5 and 5.5 have played with these more than any other toy. They proved to be so great that we purchased a second set.

Highly recommended.

text: We ordered this along with some similar items to create a "game table" at a big formal family event. Little kids, medium kids, big kids and adults all enjoyed it, and because the tiles themselves are sleek and geometric, the beautiful sculptures created only added to the look of our event. title: LOVE Magnatiles

title: Best toy in our house
text: What can I say about this product to do it justice! First of all, if it came down to only having one toy in the house for my kids to play with and them be entertained it would be these. Well we might not be able to do without the hot wheels. But if these are out they are being played with constantly. Second, they have been stepped on, dropped, crushed many times and not one has a crack. I think these things will last forever! My son has built rockets, houses, garages, towers, you name it. I have four little kids, three of which can currently play with the tiles, and they all play with them in their own way. Or they learn from each other which is awesome. They are also very great educational tools as far as learning shapes or math. They stick to the fridge so that you can make stuff like hexagons on the fridge. Baby's love to chew on them! We got the same set but in the solid colors to add to our collection as my kids were fighting over the big squares. These things are worth the investment all the way! They don't break and they provide fantastic entertainment. They're even fun for adults!

title: Compared to Playmags
text:
Magnatiles are THE name brand. You can count on them being the safest in terms of chemical make up (BPA free, lead free, etc...). They have rivets and not just glue to keep the magnets in.
They have a wide assortment of colors, especially with various sets. They have fun pieces like doors and stairs. Their isosceles triangles actually make perfect circles, unlike many other brands.

Cons would be that they’re expensive. Their magnets are also smaller than some newer brands have released.

I’m adding pics comparing to Playmags; Playmags have larger magnets. However, Playmags isosceles triangles can’t form circles, thus no pretend pizzas, cakes, pies, etc. Playmags are cheaper, but they’re also not very forthright on chemical makeup.

Magnatiles are stronger than Picasso, and have the rivets in the corner for extra durability unlike Picasso.

Don’t go for obscure off brands when it comes to magnets for toys, as they can pose a safety hazard.

Magnetic Tiles are super fun for kids. Heck, even for adults. It’s the first toy that really brought out independent play at our house, and they’re so open ended. I’d suggest a minimum of 100 pieces per child.

There’s a Magnetic Tiles Ideas group on FB to get and share building ideas.

title: Best Toy Ever
text: I read the reviews and was impressed that many found that their children would play for hours and months.  Happily and thankfully, I can say as a mom of 4 boys 6 years old and under the reviews were absolutely correct.  I just ordered 2 more 100 piece sets to add to their collection. Apparently all it took was the right toy and we can see what we thought was true before. He has an exceptional awareness in building and attention to detail. From space ships, cars, houses, castles, different designs and such.  You can make mazes pretty quickly and they can have fun breaking the design and building it right up.  The little ones are still puzzled how they stick together, but they will catch on soon enough..  We love this toy! title: Absolutely the best toy ever!  Hands Down! A must have!
text:
So, how do I begin.... I suppose with some declarations

1. I am not in any way connected to this company, although I'd like to be
2. I have no incentive for writing this review other than to spread good information based on my experience with these blocks

So, my addiction with these blocks started about 2 years ago, when my son turned 1. Given, at that time he was unable to play with the two sets we had bought form a major big box retailer. The sets happened to be 25% off at that time of year and I jumped on two boxes and stored them for a bit. When my son turned 2 the blocks started being played with. Every since its been a uphill battle to not buy more pieces consistently. At this time we have 3 sets in use, approximately 300 pieces and I have two more boxes (100 pieces each) for my sons upcoming birthday, which will put us over 500 pieces. So why are these blocks so important to our lives you ask? Why invest so much money on these blocks? Please allow me to answer in a multi-tiered fashion.

Cost:
These blocks are not expensive, not for when you think about the cost associate with one dinner for a family of 3. Go to your RedLibster or go to AliveGarden one night and tell me how much you spend. Oh.. you spent a 100 bucks on some pasta and breadsticks great... you could have had a toy your child/children would play with for 10 years and hand down to their kids one day or an item you could have easily sold on online auction sites for at least half of what you initially spent. We all know it, 'if u want something good u pay a little more'.. so lets not be delusional about the cost of these being too much. In comparison to other toys... they are but a fraction of the cost, based on the possibilities....(see below)

Possibilities:
These things are almost entirely unlimited in regards to what they will allow someone to produce. When my son first started playing with them he would make 'floors' for his trucks to drive over, then it was simple enclosure unites, then enclosure units with roofs, then villages with roads and buildings, then airports and firehouses, etc... hence the reason we need more blocks. I am having a hard time keeping up with his very creative mind.

Why:
These blocks for 100 bucks, or whatever u spend on them, trumps any other 'setting' toy you can buy, such as a TTT setting to run trains on which gets old after a while, although the tracks allow for imagination. Even with train tracks though you can only run trains on them. These pieces allow for you to, as described above, build whatever. My son has built house for his 'stuffed animals'... heck... we even built some for his dinosaurs and for him on one occasion.

Perks:
So easy to store and for the analytical/OCD type person who loves to clean up after their kids, these blocks are ideal. A few minutes and they are exactly as neat as they were when they first arrived in their original packaging. Not many toys can offer that... not to mention these avoid the infamous 'middle of the night' stepping on a (little block) and screaming murder.

So.. I am here to simply praise Valtech for their exceptional product. These blocks are sturdy, safe and break proof (or so they appear to be). I am a very hands on father and I spend countless hours with my son playing games (he is an only child, that turns 3 this coming week). I've found great joy in playing with him with these blocks and watching his brain develop in a number of fashions.. below are some of the learning benefits I believe these blocks offer:
1. Patience in understanding how long it takes to build something up
2. Mechanical Dexterity
3. Resiliency in rebuilding things that fall
4. Geometry/Shapes recognition
5. Mathematics/Counting
6. Physis; Forces; Magnetism/Leverage
7. Teambuilding
8. Creative play
9. Pre-approach
10....(more I'm sure to come as my child grows)

I DID NOT receive any sort of discount on this product. I do not receive any perks for writing this review other than knowing that I possibly helped lead you to buy these blocks for your child or children to play with. That in of itself would be rewarding enough or me and make me happy for having taken the time to review these blocks.

We have since started branching out with these blocks:
-Plays with them in the shower
-Bringing them to grandmas house
-Bringing them into the sandpit (Mr. Crabbie)

My son calls these things 'sticky blocks' and they are one of his favorite toys. We really have played with them for at least a half an hour to 3 hours for the last 6 months straight. I'd say, its a bit much, (the playing that is), however, I know with my son we are going to play..it is very rewarding to know I am doing my job as a parent and able to find some 'enjoyment' myself in watching his little brain expand before my eyes... These are the epitome of the type of item you buy to enrich your kids life. I took a while to buy a STEM toy/product in that I wanted to buy the right one... this one.. on the 4th purchase continues to reaffirm my belief that there is no better toy available out there.

Cons: None
Additional information: Magnetic Strength is good
Suggestions: Buy Base that avoids using 4 'big squares', buy a carrying case, take pictures of each of your designs

Questions? I'm happy to provide additional thoughts should you have any questions.

Enjoy.. and remember... You cant say 100 bucks is allot of money for a toy, if you are eating out each night, drink, smoke, etc...

title: World peace may begin with this toy
text: I bought this set for my 3 year old son's birthday.  He has played with them every day since.  When I needed a few minutes of quiet time so I could get some work done, I used to turn on the tv.  But now I suggest he plays with the magna tiles, and he immediately pulls them out.  His 6 1/2 year old sister and he will grab toys from each other and push and shove... until it comes to playing with magna tiles.  When the magna tiles come out, they play together clamly and quietly and share and trade the shapes they need to make a doll house or a rocket ship - this is the only toy that they will both play with and never have to be reminded to "play nicely."  When their older cousins come over, we have a living room full of kids (ages range between 3 and 12) working together to build structures.  When the structures collapse, they work together to figure out how to build something bigger and taller and strong enough to hold the weight.  Yes, they're a bit on the pricey end, but watching my kids play with them quietly and cooperatively has been absolutely priceless.

I thought we would probably only use them on rainy days when they couldn't go outside to play, but this hasn't been the case.  They use them frequently and love, love, love to build with them.  I plan on getting another set soon.

title: This is my 2nd set!
text: I have twin boys (5 yrs old) and a 3 yr old daughter.  They love building with these shapes (and not to mention myself as well!).  It's amazing to see the creations they have come up with!  I've bought a 2nd set so they can go bigger and taller!  I bought the original set 2 years ago and the magna tiles are very durable after many uses.  The hours of educational fun is well worth the price. Starting off with 2 dimensional designs to 3d is so interesting and great to see the kids advance with their imagination.  I'd gladly buy these again and would highly recommend other parents to purchase!

title: Great for kids that get frustrated easily.
text: My mother in law got this for our 3 year daughter who is small for her size and has trouble putting together duplos or tinker toys.  Magna Tiles are great because they snap together and only fit one way.  Taking apart is easy, just knock over.  They are fast fun to build and tear down.  I would rate these along with Legos and Lincoln Logs and timeless toys.

title: This is by far one of the best building toys out there
text:
This is by far one of the best building toys out there. Yes, it is very expensive (there is a learning store where I live and I purchased two sets when they had a BOGO 1/2 off which helped a lot) but these have entertained my children for more hours than I can count. Even my husband and I get pulled into building.

We have one of the starter sets and two 100 piece sets and even with all the abuse (like building tall structures on tile and having it crash or just have everything crash, because one of my son's favorite things after building was knocking down what he built), we have only had a few pieces where the plastic chipped (and we have had one set at least 5 years of heavy use now, the other 3 years of heavy use). They are pretty darn durable (beware of knockoff) and the magnets are quite strong. My son also loves to mix building materials and has used wooden blocks to fortify structures so he could make them taller. My daughter adores the set as well and since it is a "shared" gift (unlike a Lego set), if they have issues sharing I can split the sets in half so they can each build their own.

title: Better than legos!
text: Our son is not a particularly "crafty" kid - he would much rather spend his time running around and playing sports than sit and do any sort of design project.  Legos, coloring books, paint... none of these keep his attention.  Magna-Tiles are the exception.  While we don't get hours of quiet time out of them, he does enjoy the flexibility that they offer and the ease of building his visions.  He has built buildings, hockey rinks, towers, and gets excited to show them off each time.  Truly a fantastic creativity tool!

title: Worth every penny - Fun for kids and adults, Educational and Durable
text:
If you're concerned about the price, stop right now. Think about all of the $15 stuffed animals. Add up all of the $5 puzzles and other "heat of the moment" things you have bought for your kids that are unused, in the Goodwill bin or have been trashed. My son and daughter have been playing with Magna-Tiles NON-STOP for 4 years. FOUR SOLID YEARS and still going. Truth be told, my husband and I enjoy them, too. Who doesn't love building? Magna tiles are educational and fun. Playing with them enhances engineering, math, art, focus, creativity, persistence and require no batteries! My kids build with them, make patterns, count, challenge gravity...it's amazing. They are cool (because they're clear and are great colors). They are durable (sometimes clear things look foggy over time - not so with magna-tiles; they've never cracked, chipped, or had any defects). They're easily stored and always fun. Hands down the very best gift we've ever purchased for the kids. We'll update this review when we've all stopped playing with them. :)
UPDATE: AUGUST 2014 - Kids are getting older and toys are turning to electronic only. However....Magna-Tiles are still used consistently. They now build with bigger vision and creativity. The tiles still look as great as they did in the beginning. If you want to really do something outstanding, get or make your kids a light box so they can build on top. Awesome! Best toy investment ever. The bonus is how fun it is to still play with them...bring out your inner kid :)
Update April 2016 - Kids asked for more.....still going strong on durability and high usage. (I love playing with them with the kids, too. They're totally cool)

title: My 5 1/2 year old son loves these magna-tiles
text: My 5 1/2 year old son plays with magna-tiles at school all the time and I just bought them for home.  We bought the 100 piece set to allow him to build big structures.  He has so much fun and really gets creative.  My husband and I have fun playing too!  I also feel safe with these magna-tile, as we also have 1 1/2 year old.  I don't feel that the magnets will come out easy at all.  I would definitely recommend these magna-tiles.  They are on the pricier side, which is unfortunate, but worth every penny!!!!

They are expensive but they really bring out the creativity in your kids. Once they outgrow them it won't be hard to resell them. title: WORTH EVERY PENNY
text: I don't know who loves these more....my granddaughter and daycare kids or me. I thought they were pricey but they are worth every penny I spent and would like another set. They were fun playing with on the floor but they fit perfectly in my window. It was a dreary day and they were beautiful. I can't imagine on a sunny day. I also have an old coffee table that has a glass insert. I'm going to add lights under it so it can be used as a light table. These blocks will be great with it.

title: A must own toy!
text:
Throw out all the other toys and get 3 sets of these.

This is all my kids play with every day for a month now from waking to bed time. They're the best investment toy-wise we've ever made, and we will eventually be getting more. Even my 2 year old builds elaborate structures and can even go sideways off the fridge. My older girls use them for pretend play for dolls and animals. They are in use constantly.

100 pieces is a good start but not enough for multiple kids to play with without fighting. Oh well they're learning to cooperate. :)
Seriously -- this is a must own toy.

title: The fun goes on forever..
text: Purchased the first set of Magna-Tiles when my guy turned 3. We got another set of crystal colored tiles when he turned 4. A different colored set when he turned 5.. see the trend? I have a high school aged niece who also enjoys creating forms out them. So the fun never ends. I'll just have to find larger containers to hold all of them.

title: Great for the non-LEGO kid!
text:
My son is almost 8 and has never cared for Legos. He will occasionally play with them, making his own little creations, but does not have any interest in constructing a 10 million piece Death Star with minuscule bits and pieces.
I have been considering Magna-Tiles for almost 2 years. They are not a small-ticket item, so I was hesitant to invest in yet another building toy which would gather dust. My 6 & 8 year olds enjoyed building with the Magna-Tiles on Christmas evening for over an hour. My 6 year old even made a dog house and play yard for one of her stuffed animals.

I chose the clear Magna-Tiles because of the look and the bright colors. I also chose these over other magnetic building sets because I was worried about the small pieces in the other sets. I have read horror stories about the internal damage that swallowed magnets can do, and we have small toddler cousins who come to visit, so the Magna-Tiles are a good choice for us.

title: Great Imaginative Toy
text: Although these were expensive, the cost was worth it!  They were a gift for my Grandson, and that was the only gift he wanted to play with.  The next day he did not want to go to kindergarten, he wanted to stay home and build things with his new blocks.  I like that the toy makes him use his imagination and helps him think strategy on how to put things together.  I choose the 100 piece set because I wanted him to have enough blocks to make large things as well as small.  He immediately built a house and then went on to make many different things. The magnets held the blocks together well and the plastic was sturdy.  He always has to clean up the blocks when done playing, if an adult were to step on them with shoes on, I could see them cracking or breaking, but just building with, they are more than durable.

title: Great fun for a wide range of ages!
text:
My son got these for Christmas at age 2, and he loves to build with them! We've also brought them to play dates with kids up to age 5, and they've been a huge hit. The kids learn to build together and work together toward a common goal, which is really cool to watch.
One nice feature that sets Magna Tiles apart from the competition is that Magna Tiles are flat on the sides. We tried playing with a similar play set at a store at the mall, but the sides were rounded, which limited our building options to spherical shapes, as any kind of tower would not stand up.

title: Missing pieces
text: My box was missing three pieces. By the time I noticed, my kids had already used them and was not comfortable returning them to amazon. Amazon did say I could exchange or return them despite being used. However, I tried to contact the manufacturer to no avail. Now you might think three pieces is no big deal but this is an expensive set and I expect it to be full. I would recommend d the toy itself but make sure you count the contents before using them.

title: Best item we gave for x-mas - twin 4 year old boys.
text:
My wife wanted to get our twin 4 year old boys these tiles. I looked at the them and though, "eh - they look good".

I could not have been more wrong. They.... are.... awesome. My boys *love* playing with them. They'll spend hours constructing things from trains to buildings to "cars" and "X-wing" fighters. I even enjoy using them, and I'm not in the suggested age range.

Great toy. Encourages creative thinking and planning. Durable. Sometimes lost under the couch during building demolition (which is half the fun).

Highly recommended, and I'm going to buy more so we can have even bigger buildings!

title: Great tiles, but we'll buy Playmags again next time
text: Great fun tiles. We bought both these and the 100 Playmags set. I don't see any noticeable difference between them except for color or shapes. I was worried about a cheaper "off brand" being worse in quality than the origional tiles. I watched many videos and read a lot of reviews, so we bought them both. They are the same, and playmags has slightly stronger magnets. If we want more, we will be buying the Playmags.

text: This toy is awesome!  I know they are pricey, but if you watch for a deal they are so worth it. My son got these for his fifth birthday and was instantly in love with the. title: Expensive but worth it?
text: Bought for my son’s 2nd birthday. Didn’t feel great spending such a ridiculous amount of money on cheap plastic but these things have gotten so much play already, I guess it’s worth it. Very surprised that my toddler can build things on his own and has found countless uses for them. His favorite thing, of course, is knocking down whatever has been built. His much older brothers and I also quite enjoy playing with him with these as well.

title: These fabulous tiles have provided my young granddaughters with hours of creative joy
text: I liked every single thing about these tiles I bought from Amazon. The tiles are sturdy with strong magnetic sides that allow some amazingly creative "everything a child's mind could picture and want to build" be built. They are lovely, richly colored tiles with many different shapes to make creations unique each and every time my girls use them and that is every chance they get. If they aren't sure what they want to do next, they always pull out the Magna-Tiles and usually work as a team to create!!! When friends come to play, so do the Magna-Tiles! I am positive that it is their favorite toy in their five- and six-years-of-life!!!! Total "win/win" Amazon purchase!!! I am proud of myself for choosing  to get a big box because there can never be enough of them when my girls are creating what they see in their heads!!!  "This was the best present ever! Thank you. We've always wanted these for a long, long time!" That sums up why every child would both want and need Magna-Tiles!

They have created AMAZING castles, buildings, fences, ballroom floors, barns, houses, towers, jails, etc.  They hold their position really well.  Our youngest loves knocking them down if his sisters allow it!  Love the clear colors and how the kids can put dolls/toys inside them and still see them.  100 piece set is our favorite. .

title: BEST TOY EVER!!!!
text:
Our kids (ages 5 and 3) received this for Christmas, thanks to both of their individual teachers recommending it. Yes, it was much more than what we typically spend on an individual toy, but WOW!!! We never put this toy away (well, we slide it under the coffee table), because it is played with DAILY! So many things you can build, keeps them entertained for a long time AND (which is think is the best part) easy to put away... so much that I'm willing to help pickup at the end of the day!!!

I cannot recommend this product more!! Brilliant invention!!!

title: Worth every penny
text:
This is probably the best toy we've ever gotten for my uber-girlie 4-year-old daughter. She LOVES these. We bought 2 sets and she plays with them almost every day. She's had them for nearly a year and still likes to show off her masterpieces every time she uses them. We also love them because she is being treated for a condition that impacts her sensorimotor skills and her PT says these can be very helpful.

Our daughter is usually all about dolls and tea parties, but this is a great toy for when she has play dates with the super-macho, car-obsessed boys in our neighborhood. Everyone thinks they're fun! I know she'll enjoy them for years and I cannot sing their praises enough.

title: Hours of entertainment
text: Got these for my daughter when she turned 4. I wish I had purchased them years before -- like when my older child was 2 or 3. She plays with them all the time and builds elaborate castles for her princess figures or anything else. They are simple for her to manipulate and really allow her to use her imagination. They have a huge set of them in her preschool class and the teacher told me recently that the tiles had to "go on loan" to another room because the kids in her class were TOO obsessed with them. They are really great toys. I think the 100 piece set is the way to go -- smaller set really wouldn't be enough pieces to do much. Price on amazon is the best.

title: Lot's of joy. Expensive
text:
Lot's of joy. Expensive, but good quality.

I read reviews of the alternate brands and the problem with them is that they don't have those metal rivets that hold the plastic plates together. those rivets prevent the magnets from falling out (remember kids throw those around...). If your kid swallows 2 of the magnets (they are very strong!) they may stick int the intestines and your kid dies. So having these rivets really is important to prevent magnets from falling out.

title: Highly recommend and worth the extra $$ for the name brand ...

title: Better than Legos, fun way to build quickly
text:
My two boys (6 and 2) love these. The soft clicking as they snap together is such a soothing sound, and unlike Legos, these some apart with a good push. Since I feel like our house is quickly becoming a Lego museum full of masterpieces that my kids never want to dismantle, I appreciate the fact that these are actually fun to knock down.
There are only four large squares. As I watched my son open it and start to build a box, I was worried that he would be frustrated by the fact there were only four large squares and a cube needs six. But he immediately realized he could snap together four small squares to make a large square, then snap together two small triangles to make a small square! Everything that people have written about the open ended play, spacial awareness and educational value is totally true. It's a great lesson in shapes, but lead to my only issue with these.
But only complaint is about the long triangles, and I can tell this is going to drive all of us a little nuts. When put together, they ALMOST make a circle. Literally, it is a crack away from a huge gorgeous circle. There are 360 degrees in a circle, so can't imagine why they wouldn't have made these exactly 30 degree angles to all fit together. You can't even shove another piece into the gap, and the magnets aren't strong enough to allow us to pull them together into a bowl. I'm going to put away half of these pieces so my kids stop trying to "solve" this challenge.
My other suggestion is to buy a light box as a building surface. They are pricey, but if you are already paying over $100 for these, look into a light box for the amazing effect of glowing pieces. The light box is also so attractive that it encourages them to keep the pieces there, instead of scattered all over the house.

If you found this review useful, please "like" this review.

Buy them, not from Amazon though, you will probably find them somewhere else with 15-20% discount, check your local toy stores and become friends with them, it will pay off!

title: most-used toy of the season
text:
I bought these for my 3.5 year old daughter for Christmas after watching her play with them at a friend's house. A month later, she has played with them almost every day since. She builds all kinds of structures-dance studio, towers, highways, whatever.

I'm glad I bought the 100 piece set--she uses every single piece when she builds. I think the smaller set would be frustrating quickly.
I'm also glad I bought the clear ones--she likes to put the various little people we have from different sets into her creations and see them in there.

I waited for a sale at a local toy store, but it was definitely worth the price at $100 for a toy that promotes creativity, logical thinking, and problem solving. She also uses them in conjunction with a lot of her other toys.

title: The best toys EVER!
text:
Magnatiles are the only toys we've ever owned that rate an enthusiastic 5 stars from both both children and parents for fun, durability, holding children's interest (4 children for 8 years!), and educational value.

We have four children, and we bought a set of 100 magnatiles when they were 5, 4, and 1 (twins). The twins are now 9, and they have been happily playing together with them for about 2 hours today. Not a single one of them has ever broken, even through rough play and corralling Barbies, action figures, and live guinea pigs. (Yes, really!) They've even played "Demolition" and none have ever cracked.

They are expensive (usually over $1 each), but I was just remarking to my children that those were the best dollars we ever spent on toys. Go ahead and invest in the big set - you'll never regret it. The only problem we've ever had was fighting when someone hoarded too many pieces, so go for the 100-pack. I wish we had a lot more than that, even, for those times when they all play together. (Yes, they're still fun even for our 13-year-old!)

When the twins were little, they built 2-dimensional shapes on the table and loved how the big, bright shapes clicked together when the magnets connected. The older ones moved right into 3-D shapes and built diamonds, space ships, houses (and pools) for Barbie and action heroes, etc. They get put away for a while, and then they get them out and play for hours again.

The shapes are all big enough to be safe for little ones (and easily found to put away), and the magnets are all contained completely inside the tough plastic shells, so we felt completely safe letting them all play. Unless your kids play with hammers, they shouldn't be able to break these and get the magnets out. (And yes, if it were possible my kids would have done it.)

Today we were talking about the different kinds of triangles (equilateral, isosceles, etc.), and the twins were identifying the types in the set of Magnatiles. Fun and learning! What more could you want?

title: Best toy you could ever buy your kids
text: Best toy you could ever buy your kids. All ages, all neighbors, everyone everywhere loves these magnatiles. Well worth the money. Take the plunge and just invest because your kids will go wild.

title: Great, creative toy!
text: Love these magnet tiles as they are one of the few toys that my twin 5 y/o grandsons will play with together.  They already had one set and we got them another so the buildings are getting taller!

title: toy of the year for sure!
text:
yeah these are pricey (pay about 120$ by the way as some places jack it up even higher), but they are so worth it! I buy these as gifts for friends and family.

- 100 pieces is a good starter set, you may actually want 2-3 sets if you have 2+ kids as they can get really creative with more

- clear ones i prefer over the solid ones

- strong plastic that is very durable. my kids have thrown them, stepped on them, jumped on them... barely a tiny crack on 1 and most are going strong after 2+ years

- magnets are a decent strength. not too strong but enough to build a tower 5 feet high. could probably be higher if my son didn't destroy it early. i hear the knockoffs don't have as good magnets. that is important as it can affect how high you can build your models.

- good variety of shapes to stimulate their imagination. just let them explore or play guide them. either way they will come up with new things on their own. mine were building a house/zoo for the toy dinosaurs the other day.

- super easy cleanup. it is actually fun for the kids and I to clean up as they snap together well and neatly.

All in all, one of the best toy purchases i've ever made (even at such a pricey starting point). it continues to entertain them 2 years later and is super durable. I highly recommend if you can afford it.

title: Best toy ever! Intellectually-stimulating and educational and... PLAIN OLD FUN!
text: Best toy ever. No exaggeration. My 3-year-old has been interested in these for over a year now and it never gets old. Unlike other toys which collect dust on the shelf after the first few uses, this is a toy that he keeps returning to day after day. Yes, they are quite pricey and I'm as frugal as they come, but they are so worth the investment. They are much more than a toy-- they are definitely intellectually-stimulating and educational. My little one thinks of new ways to use them everyday (one day he'll use them to build a tunnel for his trains, and the next day he'll build a castle for his figurines, another day he'll build a giant crocodile or a tall tower, etc). There are so many ways to play with these and use your creativity and imagination. As a parent, I love them and feel good about the fact that he's learning about math, geometry, and a whole lot more without even knowing that he is doing it. My husband and I often find some of his toys a little boring after a while, but this is a toy that we can genuinely have fun with ourselves. We love to watch our little architect-in-training building with his Magnatiles. I have seen cheaper alternatives offered, but I can attest to the quality and durability of these tiles (our son can get a little rough when playing sometimes and these tiles have endured a lot but we have not broken a single tile to date).

title: Worth every cent.

Don't think it is just for boys, I have seen 4 year old girls play for hours with the Magna-Tiles. Might I add, even as an adult, it is fun and it boosts your creativity. title: Intriguing and Usable by all ages; very durable
text:
Intriguing and Usable by all ages: very expensive but worth it. I especially like that they are simple, and imagination is all you have to add to "assemble" them. 3 year old loves them, 6th graders love them. heck: I love them. Get as many as you can afford and build big, tall, wide... many, whatever.
The image is a castle made by some school-age kids I work with; looks like it's under siege by some chess pieces (the kids repurposed these from a Sovereign Chess set -- a game worth looking up) There are probably more than 100 pieces in use in this castle so you can see how your building supplies will add up.

Durable: these are in use by kids at an afterschool center and get used very day; as far as I can see there's nothing that could even get broken -- nothing ever has. The pre-school kids at the same site also use bins of these magnatiles.
