title: My son's favorite Christmas gift
text: The quality of Magna-Tiles is not comparable with the knock-offs (trust me, we've tried) My son just loves this set, it's the only gift he plays with every single day. Although they are pricey, we will be buying more in the near future

title: We would definitely recommend it to others
text: My 5 year old son plays with these at his pre-school all the time, so we bought one for him for home play. So far he has played with it at home as well, which means less time playing games on the iPad; mission accomplished! We would definitely recommend it to others.

title: Gets Stamp of Approval from 2 & 4 Year Olds
text: I don't know if my 30 month old would have engaged so well on his own, but with the tutelage of his four year old brother, he has taken a lot more delight in building than in knocking down, and the two of them stay busy with this almost daily.  About a week ago, I put it away on a high shelf to give it a rest.  When the toddler couldn't sleep last night, I brought it back out for him and he greeted it with delight and played quietly for more than an hour, building some sophisticated structures on his own.  These connect so much easier than Legos or similar building toys, although arguably aren't so versatile for older children.  Cars travel down ramps and under bridges, and little people live and work in their houses and office buildings.  The fact that they cling so well to one another makes them a cinch to clean up, and the kids actually like collecting the pieces and stacking them into their (separately purchased) plastic container.  Once I saw how much they enjoyed this set, I added a second specialty set that included a wheeled chassis and a hinged door to add to the fun.

title: THIS brand has great magnet strength & is fun for all ages
text:
My four grandchildren, ages 4-7 love these and play cooperatively together/share them!
Tiles can be made into anything one imagines and is a great toy that encourages creativity.
Rather expensive, but worth the cost.
I avoided other brands that were lower priced, after negative reviews stated those magnets were weak.

title: Not worth the price.
text: Kids loved it at first. Then got bored.

title: Awesome toy
text: Well made and completely worth the price. They are played with non-stop

title: The adults like playing with it too
text: Spot on gift for 2.5 year old and older.  The adults like playing with it too.

title: Fanastic Toy Worth the Price
text:
I purchased 2 sets one for my 3 year old granddaughter and one for my 3 yr 8 mo old grandson. They both love to play with the tiles and build. They both have made some fantastic buildings and designs They do not tire of playing with it.

A very creative and worthwhile product. It gives them the concepts of squares and three types of triangles.

title: Really quite great, have staying power, but not perfect
text: Initially my wife and I were a skeptic, how could this rather pricey toy be so cool that it has hundreds of positive reviews.  Well, six months later my kids are still playing with these, so a toy with staying power is a rare find and something I like (especially given the price of these things).  The kids get creative making houses, hotels, parking lots, tunnels etc.  The two year old mostly builds flat 2D things, the 5 year old is a little more creative with 3D objects.  One thing we don't like is how easily the magna tiles collapse if you build a multi-story building.  Legos these are not, it will collapse like a house of cards if there's a weak point or you wobble the surface you are building on -- thus minus 1 star.

title: Five Stars
text: MY GRANDCHILDREN LOVES THIS TOY SET.

title: He would get frustrated with cheaper building sets that would fall apart easily. My nephew is 5 yrs old
text: My nephew loves these! Totally worth it.  He would get frustrated with cheaper building sets that would fall apart easily.  My nephew is 5 yrs old.

title: Fun, engaging construction toy
text: These were the number one gift for my son. Little did we know that our 6 and 10 year olds would play with them as much as he does! We’ve made giant towers and houses and pyramids and garages and we’ve used them already for homeschool math. I absolutely recommend getting the large set like this, especially if you have multiple children.

title: Great Toy!
text:
My 4-year-old, who received his third 100-piece set of translucent Magna-Tiles for Christmas last month, asks, "Can you put MORE than five stars?"

These tiles have been through much abuse and somehow survive. They have been made into castles, 26-story towers, honeycombs, fences, floor mosaics and pyramids, and we're still discovering new ways to use them.

Great for playdates as well as solo play. As I stood in line at the toy store to buy the latest set, three other parents confessed to being addicted to them.

We just ordered a fourth set.

title: fun for all ages!
text: This is a wonderful toy for children of various ages starting from preschool. I purchased it because children in the preschool programs where I worked loved them and were competitive about getting play time with these tiles. My grandsons are enjoying them and learning to move from 2 dimensional construction to 3 dimensional building. We're teaching them the names for the 3 different triangles--isosceles, right triangle, and equilateral triangle! Adults have fun playing with the children and the tiles--can be a family activity.

title: AWESOME Magnetic Tiles!
text: This toy is awesome!!! My 2 year old daughter and 4 year old son play with these tiles almost daily (my son received a pack of 32 for his birthday about 4 months ago). These were such a huge hit with both kids that we splurged and bought a pack of 100 tiles in addition to the ones we were given. The structures and creative ways my kiddos find to use these is fantastic! Great toy, great gift! The blocks come in several shapes, colors and sizes and the kids can use their imagination to build or try to copy some of the images provided with the tiles. The edges have specific sites with magnets in them to "stick" them together. The only thing I could wish for is that the entire edge was magnetic so that the kids could be even more creative. But I still give them 5 stars.

title: Quality
text: My 3 year old grandson loves it

title: Great Building Tiles! Versatile!
text: My 4 and 5 yr old children love these!  They build every day, zoos, hospitals, animal cages, houses, towers, anything they can imagine!  Additionally they are SOOOO easy to clean up and only take the kids minutes to tidy up.  Can't say enough good things about them!

title: Grandson plays with these for hours!
text:
Initially, the adults in the house were frustrated with these, in comparison to their experience with Magformers. However, after a little more exposure, adults and 3-1/2 year old grandson were addicted to building creations.

We have all enjoyed them so much, my daughter bought an additional set to complement this one, so we don't find ourselves limited when one of us is creating along side the little guy.

title: Five Stars

They do hold together pretty well, there are some knockoffs out there that dont. They are pricey, but worth it. I look forward to getting add-on packs as gifts and surprises!

title: Great product!

title: Second Hand Inadequate - 73 Pieces Only

We like to buy second hand to reduce waste but this will make us think again.

Aside from seller swindle, good product.

title: The children love it!
text: I thought it was expensive to begin with, but after reading all the parents reviews wishing they had bought the larger set, I am glad I purchased this version.  My kids are fighting over which one gets to play with it.

title: Fun for hours
text: I love a good timeless open ended toy and this one is perfect for that. We will probably invest in more sets soon.

title: A must have and so worth the money
text:
You can see my review from a few years ago below. My boys are now 14, 13 and 10 and the magna tiles are the only toys still being played with in the toy room on a consistent basis. Not one tile has ever broken and again, we are talking about 10 years worth of daily use! What other toy is played with daily for 10 years and still looks as good as new. As I mentioned before, I am also an elementary principal. I now have 20 classes of kindergarten and first grade students and this is still the favorite indoor recess toy. I buy a few new sets a year because every teacher wants a couple of sets for recess. Again, not one broken tile and many of our sets are ten years old. Don't think they are too expensive. Instead think about all the toys you spent $30 - $40 on that were played with for a few weeks or months and then tossed aside. That won't happen with these. These will be played with often and then passed down to your grandkids.

My review from 10 years ago - Yes, Magna tiles are pricey but well worth it. We have three boys ages 5, 4, and 1. They all love playing with the magna tiles and build some pretty amazing structures. We purchased one set of 100 for Christmas and then realized we really needed another set. With two sets, there are plenty to go around and everyone has fun building. I would recommend the clear ones. Kids like to build houses and barns they can put their animals and cars into and still see them. I am also an elementary principal and we bought several sets for indoor recess and for our latchkey program and they are used on a daily basis and have been for about 6 months. They are holding up great and again, the kids love them. I see kids from age 5 - 11 playing with them at school. At home, my husband and I enjoy them as much as the kids.

title: Five Stars
text: The best toy.

title: Very durable, GREAT toy! All Ages!
text: These things are amazing and for ALL ages. My 9 and 14 year old still bust these out and play with them. They are extremely durable and I am glad I didn't buy the cheap ones. Spend the extra money for the durable ones, they will last forever!

title: Knew these would be a hit!

Their parents said they have endless hours of fun.  This year I have added the base - very important if you would like to move your "highrise" around and I also added the book of building ideas.  This is something you can add on to for years to come!

text: Wow. My sons received these for Christmas and the Magnaformers. I was shocked at price that was paid for these for what you get. The magnets in comparison to Magnaformers are extremely weak! They received Magnaformers first, so for price I was expecting a much higher quality product than even the other brand. As many others have stated they feel very cheaply made in comparison and do not lend themselves to any sort of 3D construction. I'm considering taking them back and exchanging for Magnaformers if I am able. I would absolutely skip these. Not sure what hype is! Good marketing I guess...

text: These may seem expensive, but they will be played with EVERY DAY.  The creativity and stem skills learned are worth the investment.  Purchase them early on and see the investment full.  We had our family go in on this gift for our eight year old son.  It was the only gift he received, and he wasn't a bit disappointed to have JUST one gift.  He loves these.

title: Well loved
text:
I really debated this purchase because of the price (incidentally- with Lakeshore Learning Coupons, you can get it for closer to $100 in their store). We went to the store and thought they felt flimsy (which is true- you can't lug your creations around). But they had such good reviews, and they are building + magnets which are two things my son loves, so... I bought them anyway and hoped I wasn't just buying an expensive toy to put in the pile of toys that are only awesome until they get home.

Long story not short- he loves them. He's plays with them probably 90% of the time every day for the week plus that we've had them and shows no signs of getting bored. He builds "spaceships", "tents", "cities", "garages", etc etc. He's in love. They hold his attention in an imaginative, good developmental way. He's 3.

title: Hours upon hours of creativity and learning
text:
We've had these for 8 months now, and we have had hours and hours and hours of entertainment from these MagnaTiles. My 3.5 year old plays and plays with them. When guests come over who come up with new ways to play with them (new things to build), it broadens my daughter's creativity and extends the MagnaTiles' shelf life.

Yes, they are pricey. And they are wonderful entertainment. We have started buying coordinating pieces from other magnetic tile makers, including Picasso Tile, and have had fun expanding what's possible with the MagnaTiles.

title: Hours of creative play
text: I purchase this as a gift for my grandchildren ages 5, and 2. These are children who have many toys.  They are particularly enjoying this toy and so are the neighborhood kids who visit.  It is well made and the magnets on the tiles are very strong. So, when they build with the tiles, the creations stay together and offer a great sense of accomplishment.

title: Fun for toddlers too!
text:
These tiles are awesome!!! We encountered these at a kids' museum and quite frankly I couldn't keep my hands off of them. Pretty much every kid who passed by got their hands on them too. At home they did not disappoint. Easy to clean up since they attract each other and a big hit for all ages. A visitor to our home, an architect, wowed us with his 3D creations. A structural engineer would probably not approve though as these tiles are meant to be torn down and be rebuilt constantly!

It specifies ages 3 and up. However, as far as I can tell, the tiles are so well built that I can't see how the small magnets might come out. They also stack, peel apart, and knock down easily giving our 16 month old no trouble at all. Anyways, the tiles are a good size for creating (temporary) apartments and garages for other toys and work great on the fridge too.

title: A great gift
text: My daughter loved it right away

title: Love love LOVE THESE
text: We bought these for our son last Christmas. He loves them! The 100 piece set is a must though, any less and there wouldn't be enough pieces to build any of the cool bigger structures. Our son is 3 and he spends 30 minutes to an hour every day building houses, castles, garages, rocketships. Our 7 year old enjoys playing too. We will probably be buying another set to add on for more fun.

I love the tiles which are an absolute must for any kid. However, I ended up purchasing a second set from a different brand, and it had same 100 pieces plus a little car, plus a booklet with ideas, plus a bag to hold all of the pieces together and it was better priced! Magna tiles did not offer any of the little details and was more expensive.
So the actual toy is great and is a definite yes, but you may find a better value for your money with a different brand.

title: Consistently most used toy
text:
We bought these two years ago, along with a different magnetic building set. This is by far the superior product, and it’s honestly worth the purchase price. My kids play with these 4+/7 days a week. They build together or separately, but everyone enjoys them. My 14m niece loves them, the adults love them. They’ve been stood on, crashed into, and a few have been thrown. I wouldn’t encourage that treatment, but they’ve withstood the abuse and we haven’t lost a tile yet.
This is something where more is better. We started with a 100 piece set and have continued to add to it. We currently have several sets, and we encourage grandparents to add to the collection (rather than buy junk that won’t last).

If you’re on the fence, this is worth it.

He was so excited to get them at his party and started playing with them immediately.  Then the adults joined in and we had some great sculptures and spaceships being built all around the table! Though these tiles are expensive, the fun and endless variety of things that can be built makes them well worth the price.  They are colorful and seem to be very durable.  I recommend buying the 100 piece set so your child's imagination doesn't get frustrated by running out of tiles too soon.  Also, the larger set allows for easy sharing with others, including yourself!

title: Great for creative play.. beware you will more than likely need more...
text:
I'm not a plastic fan. I really try to limit plastic in our house and, in doing so, waited a very long time to get these. A family member wanted to give to our LO as a gift, so I ordered as I knew she liked them from using them at school. We had once told friends that we were going to leave them for a school-only toy and we were told that of all the toys we could focus on that we should add these to our collection. They said the only thing we'd regret was not getting them sooner. Well, they were right. LO was so thrilled to get these and they have been used daily. I have even purchased two expansion packs so she can build bigger things. They really are great toys for creativity, understanding angles and how things works together, etc. And they are so useful when you need to cook or clean or do something that LO doesn't want to or can't be involved. Just point your child in this direction and s/he will be happy. Honestly, they are taken out without any prodding and so many things have been built. It is amazing to watch the brain just hum while using these. A reluctant (do to the high plastic footprint) huge fan.

We invested in these versus other magnetic sets that might be cheaper because a school teacher shared that some of the more economical sets don't build as well as the magnets don't hold as strongly and pieces fall more easily; and that the magnets are at increased risk of falling out. We have pets in the house and don't want anyone swallowing small magnets. We also don't want to provide a toy that creates frustration because it can't hold.

The only thing I will say is this is an expensive toy/habit, as the price point is high for what they can build with the sets. Even with this 100-piece set our LO was looking for more with her very first build. Also, the set doesn't include enough of the large pieces. To stabilize some builds, depending on what your intended child does with these, those will be needed. And I think many will find this need. They sell them in expansion packs of 8 pieces each and we've already bought two of those - $50 for 16 pieces! Do the math with this set at 100 pieces and something seems a bit off. With each new set of these we buy I can see that we'll also need to invest in those too, which is a rather hefty price tag all at once. Would be nice to see them available at a better price or in bundle packages with a cost reduction for the higher count purchase built in, as they are really pricey for only 8 pieces.

All in all, this is such a great toy for kids (just please never throw away... so many people want these that they can be reused by friends and family or schools or daycare centers, as well as many others. they are plastic so my only worry is not having these end up in a landfill).

My wife is a kindergarten teacher and will use them in her class this next year.  We will certainly be purchasing more.  Thanks

I recommend that people sit tight until they are available for purchase and are more reasonably priced. The company stated back in October that they were able to retrieve the templates from the flooded factory and that they would build another factory on higher ground. They might be available for purchase as early as April. They also promised they would be coming up with new unique sets. We're really looking forward to their newer creations!

title: Possibly the world's most perfect toy
text:
I've worked with kids for 11 years and ever since Magna-Tiles have come on the scene I have yet to find a better toy. They are almost indestructible (I have yet to see one destroyed, even in an elementary classroom, but I'm sure it's possible if your child has a sledge hammer). They invite creativity, shape sorting, color identification, building, teamwork, etc. Mostly they are a BLAST. I hate most kid toys but I'll happily help build things with Magna-Tiles for hours. Kids of all ages (from babies to... everyone) will have fun with them. They are safe (no choking hazards here!) and easy to use. I've noticed toddlers become very frustrated with duplo blocks because they can't manipulate them easily, or with blocks because they towers tumble too quickly. These tiles stick together very easily and come apart with just a little effort - so towers are easy to build and sturdy unless you choose to knock them down.

I've seen kids make stables, houses, towers, desks, caves, tracks for the Thomas trains, etc. They are perfect for every family. Skip buying almost any other toy and save up to buy a set or two of these instead. Totally worth the investment.

If not, it's worth saving up or using that next gift certificate to offset the cost. title: Not all they're hyped up to be
text:
We purchased a 100 piece set to give to our four kids for Christmas (2-9 years old), and we were super excited for our kids to open it. Unfortunately, the excitement ended when the box was opened. The three main things that we were disappointed with were:

1) The tiles look and feel very cheap. At $1+ per piece they should look fairly good. We were expecting something solidly constructed and sturdy looking, but instead found that they are simply two pieces of plastic (one for the front and back) held together by a few rivets. (a.k.a. hollow plastic tiles)
2) The magnets are very weak. Instead of having magnets lining the entire edges of the tiles, there are just a few small magnets on each side. The small magnets that are used are so weak that they can barely even hold a single tile off the ground when connected together. When you put the tiles together (on the floor) they do not hold tight and stay aligned on their edges, they simply are attracted to each other and will stay together as long as there is nothing leaning on them or putting any force at all on them. If you place a tile vertically on top of another tile, the magnets aren't even strong enough to keep the one tile vertical... it just falls over unless you have other tiles balancing it in place.
3) The tiles are much larger than we had anticipated. This wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing if the magnets were stronger, but with the magnets being as weak as they are, the tiles are just too large for them to keep connected very well.

With that all being said, my kids did enjoy the toy a little bit today (they opened this gift today). They created a few small blocks, buildings, etc., but it didn't keep their attention for very long because of the weakness of the magnets. My kids are used to magnets with a strength more along the lines Magnetix (they *love* these), and with these tiles falling apart so easily they were somewhat disappointed.

My opinion on these may change as the toy is played with some more, but on first glance and after a day of my kids playing with them, I wouldn't recommend these to others.

title: My boys love these!
text: I kept this toy in my cart for over a year trying to decide whether to purchase it due to the high price.  I finally broke down this last Christmas and bought them for my 2 year old due to all of the positive reviews.  They come in a fairly uninspiring box, so on Christmas day they were overlooked and other toys were played with first.  However, once we opened the box my children fell in love with them.  I have three boys, ages 7, 5 and 2 and they all love playing with the tiles.  They've been used and abused for over a month now and show no signs of wear and tear.  My boys use them to create all kinds of structures and then they play with their other toys in combination with the tiles.  I'm glad that I purchased the 100 piece set because between the three boys there are never enough to go around.  We are seriously considering purchasing another set so that all three boys can build their own structures at the same time.  They are great for teaching colors and shapes and my boys are quickly learning that two triangles make a square and that several squares put together make a rectangle, etc.  This is a truly wonderful, imaginative toy.  You won't be sorry that you purchased these!

title: Great Toy for all ages!
text:
I finally caved and bought the 100 peice set for my boys - 4.5 and 8. I have read the reviews on this and decided to suck it up and spend the money for the big set. I have not been disappointed - this toy is simply awesome while being so very basic.

I was a little worried that my boys may be 'too old' for it since most of the reviews are written for younger kids but I was pleasantly surprised when they both loved it and I find that the 8 year old plays with it far more since he is able to build larger creations without it breaking. Yesterday he built a house for all his action figures! I even love to sit and play with it. The pieces 'stick' together so easily yet the magnet is pretty strong so that the pieces don't come apart easily.

The 100 set is a good amount of blocks. I am not sure I would invest the $$ into a smaller set unless it was just for one child, maybe 2-3 years old. Anyone older will want to be able to make something bigger than what the smaller sets will allow. I can actually see myself getting another 100 set in the near future because the few times my boys have built together they have fought over having enough pieces.

Overall, great purchase and well worth the money. I only wish I had invested in this while the boys were younger!

text: Hmm.  Did I get this for my son, or for me?  They are great fun.  With all of those magnets, the box is fairly heavy.  You end up thinking those are going to be really strong magnets and they end up being what I'd call "strong enough" magnets.  At first I was a little disappointed, but then I realized that this ends up really teaching a lesson on building support walls, and thinking about how a structure can be stabilized.  I don't know if that is what the manufacturer intends, but it sure made me feel better.  What is important is that my son really enjoys it and so do I.

title: AWESOME for long-lasting DAILY creative play for 3-8 year olds...even if they are a little pricey - you get your money's worth.
text: We LOVE our Magna-Tiles.  We first discovered them on a visit to the local museum, who also had a light table underneath them to provide better instruction on color combination as well as building.  The ONLY reason I gave them 4 stars is because of the price-point and limited number of shapes.  Yes, they are expensive, but, unlike other toys I spent a little less on and my kids eventually tossed to the side, THESE have PROVIDED HOURS of fun for our 3, 5 and & 7 yo's who all play TOGETHER with them - for OVER A YEAR.  We are in the midst of moving and in a shorter-term housing while most of our stuff is in storage.  The ONE toy we couldn't live without was our Magna Tiles.  However, with the reduction in toy options and all 3 playing at once daily, we needed MORE pieces.  I was hesitant to pay another $120+ for 100 more pieces.  We landed on supplementing this set with the Magnetic Stick N Stack 120-piece Classic Plus, which we combined with this one for more variety of shapes - and at a little less money on a per-piece basis.  They work together perfectly.  The Magna-Tiles do seem stronger in terms of magnetic strength as well as the plastic components.  If price and shape variation aren't an issue for you - I'd buy 3 boxes of these...but we wanted variety, and we wanted economy.

text: My 3 year old granddaughter loves these Magna-Tiles!  There are enough tiles in this set to create almost anything she wants.  This is a toy to foster creativity, and I really like how strong the magnets are so that the tiles hold together easily to prevent frustration, yet they are easily taken apart by even little fingers.  The best part is that when picking up 100 tiles off the floor, the job can be done quite quickly by sticking the same shape/size tiles together and storing them in a small tub or shoebox!  As a teaching moment, one can even ask the child to stick all the small squares, equilateral triangles, etc. together, for example.  This makes cleaning up a learning time, too!

title: Five Stars
text: Love this product. They inspire creativity.

title: The best toy we have so far
text:
I told my parents that our daughter really liked to play with these at the Discovery Center, so she got it for Christmas from "Santa" (she was then 19mo). It has been over 6 months since then and she is still playing with these tiles nearly every day! Our Magna-Tiles were "tested" on other kids of different ages (1 to 5 yo) everybody liked playing with them.

None of the tiles broke so far - absolutely no problems in this area.

I first thought not to rate the educational value, but then I thought that it helped her learn better what the triangle and square look like, she now feels well what sorts of tiles she needs to take to build various kinds of houses she is building, she knows how to put the triangles upside down when she is building the roof of a wider building, she knows what kind of triangles (and how) she needs to put together if there is not enough squares to build what she wants... I think she already knew the colors when we got the Magna-Tiles, but the colors (there are 5) are great and they are also being used - to build "all green" room in the house, for example.

Using one's imagination these tiles can be used not only for building houses and castles - the colorful floor looked great; yesterday she put longer triangles in the bucket and said that those are slices of watermelon - the shape is similar to the real ones I cut myself :) ; at one point today I saw that the tiles were used as "chairs" in a "restaurant" :)

I was right when I told my parents that the Tiles have to be of clear color - it is important that she can see the characters in the houses she builds through the walls - see for herself and show the others without having to open anything. Sometimes she also makes a 2x2 square out of 4 squares and looks through it to notice "the world becoming a different color".

Even though there is a 100 pieces, I still consider them as easy to clean up, because they stick to each other and it is very easy to build up a pile and put it back in the box.

We never had any big squares at home, so we did not miss them :).

Great toy!
--------
Update: it now has been 18 months since we got the first set - she still plays with it almost every day and we got a second 100-set for her 3rd Birthday. This was probably a set #6 that we bought - we were buying some for our friends. Some people who played with the tiles at our house bought them too :)
none of our tiles are lost or broken. the second set we got had the 4 large squares.

title: You cannot go wrong with Magna-tiles
text: Best toy ever and the only one I consistently recommend to everyone.  My daughter loves magna tiles so much we own two 100 piece sets and sometimes wish for more. I'm amazed by what she can create since the effort is in the imagination, not the fitting together since they snap together so easily.  When a big structure has fallen down, we've been able to turn it into a teaching moment about reinforcement and she tackles it again.  All this is to give you a flavor of what your child will get from this amazing toy.

title: Off Market Brands are Just As Good and Cost Less
text:
I love Magnatiles, but they are unnecessarily overpriced.

This set is quite complete and perfect for my therapeutic play therapy practice. I also got two of the little wheeled car bases to add to the set. Also overpriced.

The reason that the only issue I have with the name brand is the price is because I also have a set of these by another brand and they’re basically exactly the same and the two brands interface perfectly.

Also, the other brand (I don’t know which off market brand I have since I bought them second hand), have several more shaped tiles such as tiles with square and triangle openings to them like little windows, adding to the creativity these tiles offer.

I almost like the off market brands better due to the lower cost and the expanded tile shape options (I’ve seen some brands priced on Amazon for under $30 for a set).

title: Hours of fun and imagination
text:
We bought it for my daughter when she turned two. It took her good couple of weeks to get a hang of these things, she used to get frustrated and throw these blocks aside. But once she got hang of it, she loves these blocks.
It's been 4 months, and she plays with these blocks almost every day for 30-60 minutes. I like the fact that the pieces are not in any specific shape (like windows, doors, or cars). She will be talking and playing and sometimes me and my husband will be looking at each other, surprised at what she is thinking and saying.
Using these blocks, she builds houses for all her toys, crayons, for her self, makes a row and drives her toy cars in between, builds so many things with out us teaching her.
They are a bit expensive, but really worth every penny.

title: Five Stars

title: The Big Hit of Christmas
text: There is not much I can add which others have not said.  I wanted to share my views because I was concerned that my daughter may not still like it.  In her 3 year old school class they had these and she loved them. She is now 4 and I wondered if they would still be as popular.  They are.  She plays with them all the time.  She builds houses for her stuffed animals, a dance floor for Barbie, garage for her toy cars.  This toy is used to enhance all our other toys and play scenarios.  Worth the money!  As an FYI the MSRP is around $129 so don't pay more.

text: A: These are a fabulous quality.....we researched a lot of the cheaper brands before buying these and ultimately went with these. The magnets are so much stronger than many of the other competitors, therefore the creations are infinite with these. I have used others at our school and found that the cheaper brands often don't have strong enough magnets to hold the weight of what you are trying to build. We have been slowly adding to our basic set we started with. My advice would also be to get one of the stabilizing plates for them to build on. My son plays with these almost daily. My husband and I have almost as much fun building with them as he does. Yes, these are an investment, but I see us getting many years of use out of them. Such a great toy that I plan to hold onto to pass down to grandkids...they're that great.

title: These magnets are NOT stronger than the off-brand tiles!
text:
Magnatiles and Magformers are some of the best toys ever, for the widest range of ages! However, these name brand Magnatiles aren't any stronger than the off-brand tiles, and cost twice as much!!! I was so bummed because I expected them to be as strong as name-brand Magformers.

I've had Magformers for 10 years and they're fabulous. Recently I purchased off-brand Magformers from Amazon and they have visibly smaller magnets, and my children's creations fall apart/collapse easily. The same thing happened with some off-brand magnatiles l purchased from Wal-Mart, which is why I decided to buy name brand Magnatiles and compare them myself. I was definitely shocked when these name brand tiles collapsed just as easily! I'm returning them right away.

That being said, magnetic tiles are still really fun toys! My kids and visitors play with them all the time. My 5 yr old daughter includes dolls and animals of varying sizes in her creations. The concept is fantastic. If the magnets were stronger, I would give it more than 5 stars!!

title: Better than Legos
text:
I got this set for my 4 year old daughter for Christmas after first encountering them at one of the independent schools she was tested for. I didn't know what they were then, but I bumped into them again on Amazon while looking for some educational toys. I read some of the reviews and decided to take a chance on them. I am not sorry that I got the 100 piece set. Like the review before stated, the 100 piece set now comes with 4 large 6X6 tiles.

My daughter immediately remembered playing with the tiles when she was being tested and she also recalled playing with them in a toy store she visited with her dad.

She already started building castles and garages for her play minivan. We were building (yes, I play with them too!) and discussing the different shapes. We talked about equalateral triangles having 3 equal sides and put them next to isosceles triangles to take note of the differences.

I think these are better than Legos and allows for open ended play. My daughter decided that for one of her inventions, she would just keep joining the pieces side by side instead of building up, so she had a great big flat design. I never thought about building something flat but she did.

If you can afford it, get the 100 piece set so that two people can build at the same time.

title: This is a great toy. There's really know immediate concern about small ...
text: This is a great toy. There's really know immediate concern about small pieces and choking. All magnets are enclosed. It's worth purchasing the 100 piece set.

title: Our grandson won't stop playing with them.

title: Played for everyday for three years!
text: I purchased these for my son after seeing them at his daycare center. They were an investment but he is not nearly six years old and has played with them everyday for the past three years. I do not think he has another toy I can say that about. Also after three years of daily use and abuse none of the pieces have broken and they still look new. I am going to buy another 100 piece set for my niece and nephews for Christmas. This is a great gift for all ages (my husband and I enjoy playing with them) and helpful for children as they begin to learn about shapes and mapping in geometry. If you have more then two children I would recommend buying an extra set.

title: Great toy for kids of wide age range.

title: The perfect toy!
text:
My friend had always raved about her son's magna tiles, but they seemed kind of pricey to me and I figured my kids could play with lego's or blocks, which are much less expensive.
For Hannukah this year, I decided to buy my three kids (4 1/2 year old girl and twin 2 1/2 year old boys) a set of 100 magnatiles. I was concerned that the boys wouldn't understand how to stack them up, but I was totally wrong.
I got home from work last night and my nanny and three kids were building a huge tower with the magna tiles. My nanny told me that they had played ALL DAY LONG with the magna tiles and that the kids built all sorts of things with them. I was thrilled!
They were totally worth the money - just to see my three kids sitting there all working together to build something. I highly recommend the 100 piece set. 32 pieces just isn't enough. In fact, I think we need more than 100 pieces because each of my kids wanted to build a huge Empire State Building tower!
For those of you who are scared about the price tag, I assure you it is worth the money. I store them in a clear plastic container so they are easy to clean up and store. At approximately $1 per piece, I also don't want to lose the pieces!!!!

title: Magna Tiles are the best toy money can buy
text:

The hard plastic and magnets are far superior to it's counter brands. We've been using them for months and albeit a little scratched, remain in great shape and endless fun.

title: Magna-Tiles vs Other Brands
text: The one gift my kids received for Christmas that they play with almost everyday. Sometimes we play with them without the kids. Nothing compares to the original Magna-Tiles in terms of quality. We also bought a smaller set of the Magnetic Stick N Stack for variety (doors/windows/etc) and while they work fine together, the Magna-Tiles are far superior. The biggest difference I notice is the weight of each tile. Magna-Tiles are heavier, sturdier and have a stronger magnet but my kids love them all just the same. I've had pieces of the Stick and Stack crack though because they're not as solid and at that point you have to throw them away for safety so If you're thinking about the Magna-Tiles vs the Picasso's vs the Stick and Stacks etc., I would say make the Magna-Tiles your base product and then add variety with the cheaper brands since Magna-Tiles doesn't have a lot of the interesting pieces you'll find with other brands.

text:
Great set, enough for 3 kids to play without fighting for pieces. I am taking off one star because it is sometimes difficult to put up "walls" without immediately "glueing" them with a ceiling, or they would collapse and get stuck to the magnetic "floor". Also, it is pricey, and I haven't found any real advantages over Lego duplo or Lego megabloks my 3.5 yr old currently enjoys. In fact, he can build stuff himself with megabloks and duplo, but not with magnatiles (yet? But even my 5 yo nephew would ask me for help building)
So I am sticking with Legos for now.

I love that they are incorporated into a wide range of play.  They are one of the best toy purchases we have ever made and I am happy to spend money on something that he plays with regularly and helps him be so creative.  I cannot recommend these highly enough!

title: My Kids started with towers but now its just a part of their play
text:
I got these for my girls 18 months ago (they were then aged 10, 8, and 7) because I saw they were one of the highest rated toys on Amazon. Since then, I would guess they have used them a couple of hundred times - sometimes every day for a month or more at a time. Overall, their use has more than justified the very steep price tag.

We started by building elaborate towers and shapes together (I enjoyed it too), but after a while they fell back on building simple one story houses (no roof) for their games with small animals/figures/dolls, etc. This has incredible value as thanks to the ease of use of magna tiles, they can set up a structure with rooms and furniture for their toys to live in for their games within a few minutes. It really enhances their play in a way that I never expected. As a bonus, thanks to the magnets, clean up is very fast too - even fun.

My now 7 year old (now 8) is addicted, and that's a good thing.

title: 5 year and 2 year review
text:
Perspective in 2019:

usage background: we are parents to 3 children (7, 3 year olds and a 9 month old crawler) we also host a monthly parenting support group with tons of random kids running ard.

our first set of magnatiles 5 years ago (100 pieces) we bought a second set 2 years back. The long and short of it is we are considering getting a 3rd set with our crawler joining in the chaos of building and destruction.

These tiles are costlier in Asia and we were really concerned we wld be duped into paying for a brand. We have spent days trawling through reviews and blogs and this repeats each time we plan to purchase a new set.

Primary reason we are repeated and convinced supporters of magnatiles

1. Safety. I have 3 kids so even if I am watching them, my brain zones off periodically. We rather have a smaller set of safe toy, than a larger set of tiles that has a occasional crack and loose magnet, which in my humble experience WILL Happen on that very day I am not present. This may not be an issue for older kids but we wanted something that was reliable even if it takes us (and the kids) months to save up for a set.

We have built towers off tables that collapsed. Simulated crashes. Tiles thrown in anger. Stomped on by Tiny humans morphed into anger green men. I am glad to report Everyone and every tile survived With only Some scratches.

In perspective: our 2 large square base plates from stick and stack had cracked within a year from nil obvious trauma.

A summary of blogs and reviews also listed issues with durability for other common brand such as Picasso tiles (cracked tiles) playmags (magnets loosening) and stick and stack. (this is not a paid review and I can't lie as I am a mom with 3 kids watching me. every single moment).

So In summary after so many years, we have decided again we would pay for the branding in this case, or rather For the quality control. The only other magnetic toys we have found to be of comparable manufacturing standards are magformers and tegu.

2. The magnet strength (I am not a scientist) has not been a problem for us. Normal collapses due to mechanical miscalculation serves in our opinion to challenge their concepts of balance and support so it has never been an issue for us. The boys have learnt so much and watched videos on how to improve their design.

We are also able to stick them on fridges and create patterns and shape. I'm not sure how strong these magnets should be but I'm just saying they work well enough for us.

3. Price these do not go on sale. Especially in Asia. So if you are waiting and live in Asia. Don't hold Yr breath. 😅 We have tried and are tired. Our 7 and 3 year old have taken 6 months to save 48 bucks and they might just make it in time for Christmas!

Not only does my 4 year-old love them, my 7 year-old daughter is equally enamored.  They will spend hours playing and creating castles, prisons, rocket ships, etc.  Not even a request to turn on the TV.  This is the first review I have ever done, despite ordering on Amazon for years and, again, despite sticker shock, I'm actually considering ordering another set so that we can build even more.  Very durable, good magnets, easy to clean and clean up/store.

title: Not as much variety as Magformers
text: I bought Magna Tiles for one nephew and Magformers for my other nephew, so I was able to compare the two.  Both sets are played with often.  Magna Tiles are prettier, and good for making buildings and other vertical structures.  However, Magformers are better for making 3-D geometric shapes, and they have more expansion sets to make cars, carnival wheels, construction vehicles, etc.  Also many of the sets are between $30 - $50 so it makes it easier to purchase additional sets.  You can't go wrong with Magna Tiles or Magfomers, but if you are deciding between the two I would go with Magformers.

title: Patience with these, they are worth it!
text:
Two sets of these for my son on his 4th birthday and he's building incredible things. These beat legos by far because when you step on these in the middle of the night, your feet are fine! We actually purchased him a third set because I enjoy the creativity.

It takes practice and time and patience. At first I wished the tiles had stronger magnets, but now I've come to understand and explain to my son how you build with structure and support for tall objects...just like in the real world. Some of the creations he comes up with...WOW. Once I taught him how to add support structure, he took off. Now most evenings I get asked to "close my eyes and come into the play area."

title: These are awesome !
text: My 4 year old got these for Christmas! She was already familiar with them. Playing at her cousins, and school and still absolutely loves them. We bought a small set of magformers first but those are almost double in price. I find these to be great and my daughter plays with them for hours. I actually asked which she preferred before making the purchase and she wanted these. Super easy clean up too. I don’t even have to help which is always a plus! And they all seem super sturdy too, no issues with the magnets...... about 5 minutes ago I stepped on a building and they’re all still perfectly intact!

title: Expensive but worth every penny
text: My 2 and 4 yr old boys love their magna tiles - easier to manipulate than legos and the possibilities are endless.  Clear ones are favored over the opaque ones - they seem to attract and hold better as well not sure why.

title: Pretty pricey for what you get
text:
My 3 year old grandson is fascinated with these....we bought him another set for his birthday! One set really isn't enough to be able to build
large structures. Pretty pricey for what you get, but everyone loves them. Wish they would drop the price a little...it's just plastic and magnets!

title: Amazing
text:
It is hard to express just how incredible this simple looking toy actually is. We purchased this for our 2 year old twins birthday (over half a year ago now). Our 5 year old and both 2 year olds have been addicted ever since. I was amazed at how easily our 2 year olds picked up the concept of how the pieces fit together. The 100 piece set provides plenty of tiles to create fairly large creations (homes for little figurines, towers, rocket ships etc).

One of the best parts about Magna-Tiles is how nicely they clean up. Because the pieces naturally fit together the kids can easily clean the tiles up into stacks which store in a fairly small container.

title: Great toy
text: My 3 year old daughter loves these tiles. She plays with them everyday. She has 128 tiles now and creates the most amazing structures. We are purchasing another 100 piece set for her birthday. I can't wait to see what she will be able to create. High quality, durable, cleanable product worth the price.

title: Imagination
text: Watching a 4 year building a castle …..awesome

title: Magnets strength less than playmags
text:
Magnatiles are great but I do have playmags and there magnets seemed stronger. I guess it's bit overrated and overpriced but you get good collection of pieces.
I think valtech need to improve on magnets.

title: The gift that keeps on giving. Don't let the ...
text: The gift that keeps on giving. Don't let the price scare you away from these. They are so worth it. I almost want to get my daughter another set of 100 so she can take her creativity to new heights (pun intended).

title: Fun for everyone
text:
I got these for my daughter a few months before she turned three. It has been a year and a half and she still loves them! Her older brother, who is almost nine, also enjoys them. They are a hit with every child who has came over and played with them. I wish they were cheaper so that I could give them as gifts when we go to birthday parties!

My daughter enjoys building houses and towers with them, while my son likes to make ramps for hot wheels cars. They are only of the few toys that they will both play with together! I considered getting a smaller set to start, but I am glad I went with the larger set; kids can build more and there is less arguing over pieces!

I was worried that the magnets wouldn't be very strong, but my kids have even built with them on the fridge, and they work great there, too :)

title: Best Toy Ever
text: If you are looking for a phenomenal toy that can entertain kids of a variety of ages, just break open a box of magna tiles.  Next thing you know, the kids have created awesome imaginations.

title: Great toy.  Don't give to any child who might put the magnets in his/her mouth.
text:
I bought a smaller set for my grandkids and they liked these magna-tiles so much I bought this larger set for them.

Kids don't need any instruction how to use these.

MAGNETS ARE A SERIOUS HAZARD IF SWALLOWED (JUST FYI). These tiles have magnets which conceivably could come loose. If a child swallows magnets, they can cause adhesions in the intestine, causing lots of pain, and requiring surgery to remove.

title: WHOLE family loves these
text: Bought them for my niece, everyone joined in with the fun. Now we have multiple sets for everyone. So fun!

title: Worth it!!
text: Our son received these as a Christmas gift this past year.  After over three months of daily play and lots of abuse they still look good as new.  Highly recommend Magna-Tiles over any other brand.  We've tried others and Magna-Tile pieces have the strongest magnets.

title: Grandson loves this product
text: My 7 year old grandson loves these tiles.  He frequently asks for more of them so he can build bigger and "better" structures.  I think they are expensive, but considering how much he truly enjoys playing with them and the fact that it stimulates his mind at the same time, I find the Magna-Tiles to be worth it.

title: Lots of fun!
text: The children love playing with Magna-tiles. They spend a lot of time creating their masterpieces. They are easy to use and easy to clean up.

title: Daughter in laws asking for it!
text:
Magna tiles are the best 'toy' u can give ur grandkids!!
When asked separatly, what to give the kids for holiiday or bday, all said magnatiles!

title: Fun for all
text: 2 year old just likes to knock them down but they are so fun for me to build that I don’t even care. Everyone says they grow into them

title: great toy!
text: Provides hours of building fun. My 2 yr old daughter and 5 yr old son love these. I highly recommend.

title: Who doesn't love Magna Tiles
text: Who doesn't love Magna Tiles?  Be sure to buy a few boxes as 100 pieces sound like a lot, but they arent!  At least, not for my builder.

title: Keeps kids entertained for hours!
text: This is the second box I purchase.  The first was for my daughter and son, and the second for my nephews upcoming birthday.  My son is 18 months old and has learned to build cubes with the tiles, so it really helps with motor skills.

title: Can you give 10 stars?!?
text: Not a day goes by in our house that these aren't played with. So cool how they work, so pretty to look at with the clear colors and so hilarious to hear the explanations of what a 4 year old's mind comes up with when tells me the story of what he created.  Today is was a castle with poky spires to keep out the fire breathing dragons attacking his kingdom!

title: Minor complaints, Superior Quality
text:
First, a minor complaint, there are not enough tiles in this set to build the castle picture on the actual box. That might not be a big deal for some kids, but my toddler was pretty upset we couldn't build that exact picture when we first opened the box.

Second, the magnets on Magna-tiles are noticeably stronger than Picasso Tiles. The plastic also feels a better quality. That being said, if your little one doesn't have good hand strength yet, you may need to help them separate the tiles. Or Picasso Tiles may be the better option for you.

Overall, we are big fans of Magna-tiles and plan to expand our sets. My husband and I even find ourselves building when our kid isn't there haha The quality really is superior to the cheaper versions and I feel they will last a long time.

title: price
text: Ridiculous price for plastic pieces with magnets on the edges.

title: Best gift!! Hours entertainment!!
text: Best gift!! Boys and girls, multiple ages!!

title: Magnets Weaker Now
text: It used to be that you could preassemble a sphere, pick up the center tile and the shape would click together as you lifted. We had an off brand that was weak would not do this so we coughed up the money for two sets of this premium-priced (over 2X) product only to discover that the magnetic strength of these tiles is no longer what the old set was.

title: Should be a staple toy for every child
text: Our 3 children never get tired of their magnatiles. They pretend to make "presents" by putting toys into the boxes they create;they make elephants, shuttles, houses, farms, etc., etc, etc. Beautiful colors- you can experiment with color mixing in the afternoon sunlight or on a light table. We have had this set for 2 years...not a single broken tile after much wear! Save the money you would have spent on some type of noise making, headache inducing, tired of it in 1 hour toys...go for the translucent magnatiles! My only regret is that we don't have 2 sets!I even enjoy picking them up, they make a little click, click as they magnetize together in a stack. These can even be played with by toddlers since they do not have any external pieces to bite or swallow.

title: Best Toy Ever
text: This may be a very expensive toy for most but it is well worth the cost. I've worked for two day care centers and this toy was played with the most and is still well loved. So much loved, kids fight over them to play with. I bought them for my own daughter when she was two last year for Christmas. She still to this day plays with them everyday. This toy has helped my daughter to be creative with building, learn through trial and error and most of all it is fun for her. If you want to buy a child a gift for their birthday, Christmas or any special occasion your money won't be mindlessly waisted because this is the best toy ever!

title: Perfect for kids
text: Loved it and the kids can't get enough.

title: Five Stars

title: Expensive but worth it!
text: I got this for my great niece and nephew, 4 and 7 years old.  They BOTH loved them!  The girl fashions cakes from the tiles and both make all sorts of buildings.  These are the best magnetic tiles around since the magnets are strong and therefore easy to build with.  The structures, or cakes, hold together well, even when very tall!  The colorful see-through format is a plus.  They are expensive and I wondered about that, but seeing how well designed they are, I think it was a great purchase!

title: Five Stars

title: Every kid needs these!

title: Love these tiles
text: I saw these tiles at my son's pre-school.  My son loved them and I also found them to be addictively fun to play with.  We don't buy tons of toys for our kids, but this one I thought: they will use these and will like them for a long time.  So we bought them and we leave them out.  They are fun to just fiddle with as you talk on the phone, and the kids are always using them to build structures, roads for cars, or just for making designs with. The one small drawback to them is that you cannot step on them or they will crack, thus my 4-star rating for durability.

title: Wonderful product

title: Never too many MagnaTiles!
text:
We purchased the 32-piece version of the set for my son's 3rd birthday and it has been by far one of his favorite toys!

We first encountered Magnatiles while visiting our local children's museum, where he played with them for over an hour, and I knew we had to have them.

I intend to purchase a 100 piece set in the very near future, because he has had so much fun with the 32 pieces, but I feel that he could do so much more, with more Magna tiles

title: Watch around kittens (small animals)
text: I love our magnatiles! We’ve had ours for almost 3 years. We’ll be buying more this Christmas to add to our collection. My kids play with their matchbox cars, littlest petshop, plastic animals, hamster, etc. with these. We have never had a problem until today. My son was playing and I went to the bathroom; come out to find my kittens head stuck in one. Still not sure how it happened but it did. Took a little time but was able to get her head back through. Obviously, magnatiles and kittens don’t go together.

Little ones make 2-dimenson patterns so far and he creates very nice buildings. This toy is easy to care for and very durable. After 3 years of play (not gentle at all) the pieces still look like new.

text:
Fantastic toy.

title: 2 Year Old's Favorite Toy
text:
I bought these based on the rave reviews from Play at Home Mom, and we haven't been disappointed! My two year old can build intricate 3D structures with them (everything from multi-roomed "caves" to hexagonal pyramids), and has played with them almost every single day in the ~5 months we've had them. They are durable enough that he can hide the dog's ball in the structure and shriek with delight when the dog pounces to send his tower crashing down and retrieve said ball! We mostly use them on carpet though - repeated crashing might scratch a wood floor? I bought a divided plastic tray at the dollar store to store them, as they don't currently come with a storage box.

Note: Wait to buy on Amazon until the price drops back down to ~$100 (scalpers went insane over the holidays!), or buy from Discount School Supply.

text: After playing with these at vacation bible school, we asked Grandma for a set for Christmas.  My girls, ages 6 and 4, literally play with these everyday still six months later!  They make pens for animals, houses for little dolls, and of course many, many towers.  The girls never notice the educational value since they're just so much fun.  We have the 100 piece set and that's not even enough.  I'm going to be checking for sales so I can get at least the 32 piece set to go with it.  Lots of people leave reviews about boys really liking these but even for my girly girls these really are one of the most played with toys.  Very much worth the investment!

title: Greatest toy, durability, tons of fun, be prepared to spend time on the floor with your children!
text: Not sure how many of you read these reviews, nor do I understand why there are no reviews on this product. But, shame on all who have purchased this product and NOT left a 5 star review. My now three year old has had endless hours of enjoyment with these tiles, along with myself (daddy) and and other children who have played with them. These are BULLET PROOF, to my knowledge not ONE of these have ever broken, been a safety issue or defective in anyway. Right now I am ordering the second set for him, his imagination has grown to point that you never know what is next on his agenda to build. Great learning tool while being extreme fun! While in Afghanistan the local JAG officer had purchased these for her children, and introduced me to these, wow, greatest toy investment I've ever made! There are other manufacturers selling magnetic tiles, not sure of their quality but, these I promise, are everything you can ask for an more.

title: Worth it's price
text: We've had this set for over a year now and our little girl (now almost 5) still loves it. She loves building and uses all the shapes and can still make-up new constructions. We've also had fun combining with her marble run and Thomas the Train set to make additional tunnels, bridges and buildings - sometimes placing little flameless tea lights inside some of the buildings to make them shine.  She's put her little plastic animals in the buildings she's made at times. It's just one of her most used, fun toys!

title: Excellent investment!
text: My four year old daughter plays with this set at school and the teachers have remarked on how much she likes them. They also recommended splurging on the 100 piece set and I'm very happy that we listened. She received this set for Christmas has been playing with it every day now for the last two weeks. Seriously. These tiles are amazing. The possibilities are endless and I highly recommend splurging on the 100 piece set. I couldn't imagine her being as engaged with the smaller set for this long. And I can see how as she grows up the tiles can continue to engage her and her growing imagination. She will not outgrow these quickly. Her two year old brother enjoys playing with them as well and just stacks them. He loves the sensation of the magnets drawing the tiles together. Also, the clear pieces added another element to them that more fun. I can't say enough good things about this product.

title: Tiles collapse easily into each other
text: After reading the reviews, I really thought I couldn't go wrong buying these tiles. But so far my 4 year old has no interest in them. He gave them a try, but he can't pick up the structures he builds because they immediately collapse into each other. I'm really surprised this isn't frustrating for at least some kids. But I thought I'd add my experience to the totally positive reviews just in case you think your kid might be that 1 in 100, like mine, who finds this an irritating experience.

title: Would give negative stars if possible
Exceptional quality.
text: This is the second set I bought and they are worth the price. They last while being used by two young boys. No cracks. No breakage. My grandchildren love them!!

title: Great quality, encourage creativity, kids never tire of them!
text: We have Magnatiles for our grandkids to play with when we watch them each one day a week.  They are now 5, 4 and 3, and never seem to tire of these at all. They build great houses and garages for the Paw Patrol pup figures and vehicles, and even for stuffed animals, have done mazes on the base plates (more about them in a second), and the little guy even likes to write out his letters on the floor using squares and triangles.  I started with the 100-piece Magnatile set after reading a bunch of reviews.  These are the pricier choice, but I believe the quality is worth it.  It's been over a year and we haven't had a single problem with any tiles.  I also got a set of two 12x12" baseplates from ShapeMags, because Magnatiles does not offer baseplates, and find that their quality is also excellent.  We find the baseplates invaluable to aid stability when building large and tall constructions.  They also make it easier to move the constructions, if necessary, once built. Since that initial set, I have added another large set, two sets of the Magnatiles Rectangles, the "House" set, and the set of two car bases.  All were great. Kudos to Magnatiles for making tiles in almost all the rainbow colors (there's only one blue, so no "blue and indigo" is possible). The kids are obsessed with rainbows and enjoy using the color tiles in purposeful patterns. Really pretty! I totally recommend these as a wonderfully creative toy that the kids will play with for years.  Adults like them, too! I can see another 100-piece set in our near future! (We have lots more pictures of the bigger constructions but I had trouble finding ones without the kids in them!)

title: Encourages creative building - suitable for age2-teens.
text: Excellent building material- allows kids to create buildings, airplanes, furniture from their imagination rather than by following directions. Feel and appearance of tiles are very inviting.

title: Five Stars
text: excellent

title: One of the best toys ever!
text: I purchased the set of 32 from a local store to have on hand when the grand kids  (7, 6, 4, and 2) come.  They were a hit.  Needless to say, they always needed more to build a bigger structure. The children had a hard time waiting their turn.  The older two usually built 3-D structures.  The 4 year old started with laying them out in a 2-D design, trying to place all the shapes edge to edge. I found that he packed them in his suitcase when it was time to go home.  Even the two year old enjoyed putting two shapes together. Seeing that each child had their unique way of playing with them and knowing the importance of building geo-spatial skills in children, I decided to get the largest set, despite the price.  These Magna-Tiles are well made and good for kids of all ages.

title: Lacking Costomer Service and Quality
text: One of the large squares broke during normal play and building; exposing the magnet and creating a hazard.  I contacted the seller requesting a replacement, but they did not deem it fit to respond.  Will not buy again unless the company takes action to correct their wrong.

The 100 piece set is definitely worth the extra money, as even with that many, they get used up very quickly. Having the larger set allows 2 kids to be able to play with it happily.

They are expensive, but I believe they are worth the money.  Along with constructing buildings, mazes, etc etc, the kids also talk about color mixing, shapes, magnets, and more!  We've only had them for a week, but they've already been subjected to rough play with no breakage.  What a great learning toy!

title: Still playing with after 5 years
text: I obviously don't need to tell anyone how great magnatiles are -- other reviewers have done that.  I did think I could add the following:  my very rough twin boys got their first magnatiles at Christmas almost 5 years ago.  We have never had a broken one (a few tiny chips at most), in spite of the fact that they love demolition as much as building.  My boys are now 7 1/2, and they are still among the most played with toys in our home.  There is never a week that goes by that they aren't building something.  Recently I used them to explain "squaring" numbers and square roots.  Their second grade friends enjoy them when they come over, and even some early teen cousins found them fun to experiment with.  So if you are on the fence because of the price, remember that not only will your preschooler enjoy them this year, but for years to come! (We started with one 32 piece set, added another, and then bought the 100 piece set the next Christmas.)

title: The Magna Tiles really engage my 3 greatgrandchildren, ages ...
text: The  Magna Tiles really engage my 3 greatgrandchildren, ages 3 to 5.  Originally bought the 74 piece set at a local store.  That set came with 6 of the large tiles.  So when I ordered the 100 piece set I expected at least six of the large tiles, maybe more.  There are only 4 large tiles in the 100 piece set.  174 pieces and they can't build two boxes or make a two story structure that size as they would lack a roof.  They are having a blast, but if you as an adult, have expectations related to MORE large tiles, damp them down.  Or get a second 74 piece set and save $20.

The price is kind of on the high side for a non holiday gift, imo (I bought the first set as a Christmas gift), but the kids were willing to split the cost 4 ways with me. text: My granddaughter on her 3rd birthday received a flood of cute, flashing, singing, tuneful toys. And finally there came this set of 100 magnetic tiles, which she instantly started working with, and that was it for the rest of the day. They're not cute or flashing, they make no noise, but they turn out to be perfectly captivating. And oh yes, I found my own sweet 70 year old self down on the floor playing with them as well !

title: Hands-down the best toy I've ever bought!
text:
My 6-year-old daughter got the 32-piece Magna-Tile set for Christmas and she LOVES it! She's been asking for more pieces, so I just sat down to buy the big set. But after doing a little research I discovered that the 100-pc set does not come with ANY of the large 6"x6" squares shown in the picture! That's a real bummer, as the big squares are really all you can use for large, stable floors and ceilings. I was all ready to drop the big bucks on the big set, but now I'm not sure about that based on the lack of big squares. I know, it sounds like it shouldn't be that big a deal, but try telling that to the Queen of the MagnaSkyscrapers!

UPDATE: Apparently they've changed what they include in the box, so that criticism may not be valid any more. I just wanted to chime in again to say that my kids STILL play with this toy almost every day! Amazing!!! I ended up buying more sets and they've been so worth it. I'm sorry to see that the company was so affected by the flooding in Thailand, as it appears the sets are almost impossible to come by at the moment. Hopefully they'll be able to weather the storm (no pun intended) and get the supply up again as this is really hands-down the best toy I've ever bought. The regular price is around $100 for the big set, so unless money is no object don't pay the crazy inflated prices scalpers are getting now. $100 was a stretch for me, but it was SO worth it. Best toy ever.

title: Excellent value
text:
I had a little sticker-shock when I bought Magna-Tiles, but they are 1000% worth every penny. It is an awesome concept, and a fantastic toy.

Another big PLUS is that they stack very neatly for when they get put away. My two kids (4 and 2) actually enjoy cleaning them up - WHOA, AWESOME!

I recommend them highly, and will be getting them for my neices and nephews this year.

title: Lots of fun.
text: My son LOVES this!.. I do to.  Lots of fun.

title: Buy this and then BUY MORE
text: When you think you have enough, buy another set! We begged our family to go together and gift these to us for multiple birthdays in a row. They are the only toy that gets played with EVERY DAY! Enjoyed by 1-year-olds as much as 10-year-olds. Heck, I love playing with them and wish we had more pieces, so I could do my own creations. 😂 I have 3 kids, currently ages 2, 4, and 9. This is a favorite toy for all of them.

title: spacial recognition
text:
Children learn to recognize and anticipate 3-d space.
Even toddlers enjoy building structures.
My granddaughters class uses these tiles.
Buying our own set gives her more time to explore.

This is a needed hands-on skill.
The children play for hours and hours at a time.

title: ... 4 year old and my 1 1/2 year old love these tiles
text: My 4 year old and my 1 1/2 year old love these tiles.  You can make so many things with them and however you put them together they stay and grow.

title: Best Toy In Our House
text: By far the most engaging and creativity inspiring toy that our kids play with - together - for hours and hours at a time.  We have a 5 year old boy and our daughter just turned 8.  This has been going on for about 2 years, and our son's first desire for his upcoming birthday is more Magna Tiles.

title: Love these!

title: Magna tiles for my grandson!
text: My precious grandson is a builder.  He has several sets of Magna tiles and builds castles and car washes and other creative  fortresses all over the house.  One has to be careful not to run into these masterpieces and break his heart when they tumble.

title: My grandkids love the Magna-Tiles
text: My grandkids love the Magna-Tiles.  This is the one toy they play with the longest.  It helps them use their imagination and brings out their creativity.  And I love it when they ask me to help them with their latest creation!

title: A great toy, but prepare to buy additional sets if multiple kids play at once
text: My kids love these Magna Tiles and I love seeing the creations they make from them. There are only two downsides: 1) they are quite expensive and 2) you will likely need more than you think, especially if you have more than one child. 100 pieces get used up quickly; I ended up buying another set of 100 plus and additional ~10 pieces for my two children, and we often find that it's hard for both kids to make exactly what they want.

title: Sturdy and magnets are strong
text: Great toy for toddlers! He loves stacking them and is amazed at how the magnets stick to one another. The magnets are really strong. Love this brand.

title: Magnatiles are great.
text: My grandkids ages 2-9 loved them! We added on to the set with a magnetic train set and extra car carriage.

title: 4 and 6 love these Magna-Tiles
text: My grandchildren age 2,4 and 6 love these Magna-Tiles!

title: Perfect for children with limited fine motor skills.
text: My grandson will be turning 5 in 3 months. He has a severe seizure disorder and is on a serious amount of medicine so his fine motor skills are affected and his hands shake badly. He cannot use regular building toys, like duplos because his hands shake too badly to be able to line up the holes and nubs and tinker toys because of the need to put a stick in hole or Lincoln logs, you get the jist. These came yesterday and he and I and his twin sisters (2 1/2) built with them for an hour. He easily made very complicated and beautiful structures and was so proud of them. These magnetic tiles are the perfect building medium for a child with poor fine motor skills to have success and pride at something he couldn't do before. I loved to build with them too. The geometric shapes are nice because the grandkids have to figure out what shapes can fit together and where to place them. With the other building sets I have, don't have to use as much reasoning and spatial skills. Even the 2 year old twins were noticing if there was an area could put a certain sized triangle in they would pick the correct one of the 3 and turn it around until it lined up and then add it to their creations. No help from me. I am so pleased with this set and, even though so expensive, am here to order a smaller set already. We sat in front of the glass patio doors while building and the sun shining through the tiles made them just beautiful.

title: Another MagnaTile fan
text:
My grand daughter (who lives with me)has magnatiles at her preschool, and nearly every day we'd go to pick her up in the afternoon, she'd be playing with them. So we decided to buy the 100 piece set for our home. She plays with them daily, building boxes and castles and cages for her other toys. We've showed her how to make new shapes, and she picks it up immediately and starts using the new shapes into her own designs. I'd guess she plays with them at least 2 hours per day, more than any other toys she owns.

I definitely recommend them. They also keep her occupied when I'm too busy to be her entertainment, and it's much better for her to use her brain than to park herself on the couch in front of the TV.

They may seem pricey, but well worth it. I have it 4 stars on durability only because they are plastic, and if they get stepped on (by an adult because they are on the floor or something) they could crack. Kids may trouble damaging them, though.

title: Great Set!
text: Wow. That’s all I can say. This set is AMAZING! I got a previous set of the hundred piece set about five years back and still have it. However, the Magna Tiles are sort of scratched and dirty now, so I got another set for my birthday. They are so shiny and magnetic. I suggest getting this set and maybe another set too, for you can make some pretty amazing creations. This set came with yellow, and it didn’t a few years ago. I suggest using your set on a carpeted floor, or just taking down your creations really carefully. This is a great set, although if you’re planning to store it in the packaging, it might not work very well. I store mine in a big plastic box, but the box that the Magna Tiles come in is sort of thin cardboard. Overlooking that, this set was a great buy and still is! I hoped this review helped you! By the way, this review was written by me, an eleven year old boy, so you have a real kid's review.

title: Magna-tiles are a stimulating educational material.
text:
It is important that children can see the magnets in these building blocks so they learn that plastic pieces do not stick together. It is the magnets that hold the plastic pieces together.

The shapes of the pieces and the way they fit together challenge children to think in geometric ways.
