title: Definitely go for the big set
text:
My daughter played with these in a preschool we visited. She talked about playing with the "magnet blocks" for a while. It wasn't until I went back to enroll her did I realize what she was talking about. She sat right down and played with them again and when it was time to go, she didn't want to leave. In looking for a present for her 4th birthday, I remembered these blocks and found them on Amazon. It came down to these blocks or the Leapster (and that was really a bribe so that I could play with our iphone). This was an easy choice and I am pleased with it. She saw me browsing the listing on Amazon and immediately said "Oh, can I build that?". I don't know if I'll be able to wait until the 11th to give it to her! I was very tempted to buy the 32 piece set. I know shipping is free for this item, but my delivery estimate ended on the 14th, so I went ahead and paid for the shipping. At $126 this was a pretty big toy investment for me, so I read each and every comment. I decided to heed the advice of parents who said to spring for the 100. Looking at this box (and I'll confess, I did play with it them briefly)- we're going to need more. In the end, I decided to buy these because we spring for educational toys. We've never purchased a Fisher Price or Playskool toy that we've felt was a good use of our money, or that we didn't want to toss. My children loose interest in them too soon and they take up too much space. I wanted to get a building toy to develop spatial awareness and creativity, but didn't want to be stepping on legos the next decade. This is a fantastic alternative to that, and I think my kids will like them better. Yes, these are expensive, however, I anticipate that these will be well used, by all three of my children for a long time, which makes them a better value than cheaper toys that are forgettable. Save yourself the grief and buy the bigger set, if only that it's more bang for your buck. I hope this set lasts us until our next birthday- 8 months from now. I'll be getting my younger daughter a set then.

The only complaint I can think of is this: My daughter is a very visual learner. I would have liked to have some type of instruction book (other than the illustrations on the back of the box) for her to use as a reference.

Point is, you don't have to keep flipping the product over until you get the magnetic connection - it seems to be there regardless. That's an added bonus, because my child doesn't get frustrated over the product falling to connect at any point during play time. title: One of the best toys out there for kids,hands down!
text:
My daughter discovered Magna-Tiles at her preschool at age 4. They had a large set of translucent Magna-Tiles which could be used on a light table which illuminated her structures from the inside. We started getting a package for her for various holidays until we have built up a fairly large collection. She is now 8 years old and still loves them.

As stated by other reviewers, the beauty of this toy is their open ended ness. She builds mazes for her guinea pig, stained glass by building them against our windows, and amazing structures that defy gravity. Kids of all ages as well as adult guests at our house love them. My sister-in-law borrows our set to teach geometry lessons to her 4th graders a couple times a year. I highly recommend the translucent ones. They offer more flexibility and seem to appeal more to kids. I also suggest getting the 100 piece set. It it a much better deal per piece than any of the other smaller sets.

title: WORTH EVERY PENNY
text: We've had this set and a smaller set for a couple of years.  I hesitated to buy them because my son's preschool classroom had them and I thought if we had them at home too he might get bored with them.  I got them on sale at a local independent toy store but I can tell you this is the best investment I've made in ANY toy.  He's built so many different things with magna tiles: a barn, the Titanic, Superman's Fortress of Solitude, the Sears Tower, the Batcave, Batmobile, many different forms of planes and space ships, and many more that I can't recall.  I have a whole digital album dedicated to his structures.  My daughter, at age two, also really enjoys playing with them, at this stage mostly sorting colors and exploring how the magnets attract and repel each other, building small structures, and knocking down her brother's large structures :)  They've held up really well to the use and abuse, but we do have a few pieces that are starting to crack at the edge.  Moms and Dads can have a lot of fun with them too--I highly recommend!

title: Five Stars

title: Brilliant building toy for two-year olds and adults alike!
text:
From his second birthday, these quickly became one of my nephew's favorite toys. I bought these for his birthday and both he and his parents *really* enjoy playing with them (as do I). The colors are beautiful and they're extremely well constructed. The magnets are completely protected so there's no concern that they might be removed and swallowed.

Two is still a little too young for him to enjoy playing with them completely alone, but he participates actively and move tiles around as he wants. Mom & Dad usually build the main structure and he makes changes and requests.

He especially likes to use them to make parking garages, roads, hangars & airports for his cars & planes. He is able to add and remove tiles to seal them inside and loves having little things hidden throughout his structures that he can get to himself. Even on his second birthday it only took him a few seconds to realize he could add or remove tiles to do this: they're completely intuitive.

The magnets are cleverly designed so they can spin, so there's no trouble with polarity. The magnets are strong enough that it's pretty easy to build skinny towers that are several feet tall. These are lots of fun for a little boy to destroy!

He loves to crash into them with his die-cast cars and planes, and they've held up quite well despite countless crashes. The first set of tiles have gotten a bit scratched up so they're not quite as pretty, but they're still smooth and perfectly functional. They hold up well even when stepped on by an adult with shoes on hardwood.

He started with a 100-piece set and we just added this 74-piece set, which is opening up even more options for cool constructions. I think there might be even more coming in his future, as I think he'll play with these for years. Unlike Legos, the ability to snap new tiles on in any direction makes it easier to just keep building up and out without a master plan, so you can never have too many tiles!

Don't overlook the possibility of using these to make flat structures like roads and tangram-like patterns. It's fun to make buildings, castles and towers, but there are lots of possibilities for flat creations as well.

There are other brands out there that are a bit cheaper and that have some more specialized tiles like windows & cars. They aren't constructed as well and the magnets are not as strong. My suggestion is to start with Magna-Tiles and maybe add some other sets once you have a good base set of tiles and the kids are a bit older. Having a few window or arch pieces would be fun, but there are countless possibilities with just the main base pieces without a need for more specialized tiles.

The only real frustration my nephew's had with them is that it's very tempting to want to build little rocket ships out of them and fly them around, but they fall apart fairly easily when he flies them around, which sometimes can leave him a bit frustrated. I don't think this is a design flaw, as if the magnets were much stronger I think he'd have a hard time pulling them off in other situations.

Overall I can't recommend these more strongly. They're lots of fun for a two-year-old child and his or her adult friends. I suspect my nephew will be happily making buildings on his own by 3½.

title: An all time favorite
text:
This has got to be one of the best toys for toddler and young children. We love it. The magnets are not so strong that it takes a lot of effort to pull apart. Some reviewers complain that they are not strong enough to hold the pieces together for long, and I will disagree. Yes, they do get knocked over, or if you are not balancing properly, they will fall over, but that's the beauty of the game. This is not meant to be some rare earth magnet game that will hold all pieces regardless of how you put them together. It teaches focus, balancing, and some precision.

My children and their classmates all began playing with the MagnaTiles when they were 2 years old. And you can watch them progress in complexity. They start with 2-D objects, connecting them flat on a surface, then eventually they venture into 3-D objects. It exercises their eyes-hands coordination and other skills. My children would play for 40 min stretches which is a long time for 2 year olds, and can spend a while raining afternoon playing with these. We own both the 100-pc set and the 48-pc DX set for added interest and because believe it or not, 148 pieces is barely enough for two kids.

title: One of the best toys ever
text:
As the mom of 2 boys, ages 6 and 8, I've seen a lot of toys come and go from our house. These are definitely one of the best.

My youngest son was introduced to magna tiles at daycare when he was 3. He was always playing with them every single day when I went in to pick him up. At 4, he asked Santa for his own set of magna tiles, and knowing how much he loved them Santa got him the 100 piece set. He and his brother played with them almost every single day that year. Their only complaint was that they didn't have enough tiles to build what they wanted. At 5, my son asked for another set for Christmas and Santa came through with another set of 100. Now at 6, almost 7, my son is asking for even more magna tiles, and I'm back for a third set of 100. He still plays with these all the time, and his 8 year old brother plays with him.

They love these so much, and it is amazing what they build with them. Their creativity knows no bounds with these, and they never get tired of them. On top of that, these things are tough. Even our original set is still going strong. We haven't had a single magna tile show any damage other than minor scratches.

I know they're expensive, but when you factor in how much they get played with they're actually a bargain. I've bought so many toys that were a total waste of money because they never really got played with, or broke too soon. Not these.

I would recommend these to anybody. My only regret is not buying some sooner. Be aware though that you do need alot of these to really build anything. I would say the 100 piece set is really the minimum except for maybe really young children.

I also highly recommend getting a couple of the large 1-foot square tiles that are availble from another brand. They work great with the magna tiles and really make building large structures easier.

text: I'm a little disappointed with this product! I researched for about a month the difference between picasso and the magna tiles because of the huge price difference. I wonder if lakeshore has better product. I'm really disappointed I spent the extra money for something that really wasnt worth it. I could have got the picasso and saved $50

title: Great Gift from Grandparent
text: Bought this for my grandchildren and it was well worth the investment! A hit with two toddlers, ages 1 and 2 during supervised play. Due to their ages this item is not kept with other toys so parents or nanny are always present when they choose the tiles for play. They like them so much they just stay on the coffee table in a basket and the children play with them every morning while waiting for mommy to make breakfast. The tiles are also a favorite of the 2 year during his special time with mom and dad after little sister goes to bed. Pricey but well worth it for the fun and enjoyment as well as the visual spatial and hand-eye coordination learning!

title: .Best new toy at preschool
text:
Browns Valley Preschool has 25 years worth of toys. Magnatiles are my favorite of all the toys we have bought in the last five years.

They are accessible to a 2 year old and challenging to the most advanced five year old. They are rugged, beautiful, with great

potential for spacial, creative and fine motor learning in ways that are 3 demensional and geometric, and create different

understanding than those of blocks, legos. tangrams etc. They are in use all day and all year with both genders and are especially

inviting when used on a light table. They are the best new thing for preschools.

title: Has been used for years - One of the few that survive the test of time
text:
Magna-Tiles first came to my attention when my oldest son was in Kindergarten (2013). The YMCA after school program had a LARGE (500 piece) set they kept onsite at his school for the kids to play with.

Each day that we picked him up, boys and girls alike were playing with these things. These kids would be completely focused on a project: building a city together, making roads and garages for matchbox cars, creating beds for dolls - whatever they could think of. These things were 'anything they wanted them to be'. They were always pulled out and being played with, each day. They were either the main item they were playing with (such as towers, buildings, etc.), or they were accompanying the other toys they had out (streets for the Lincoln Log town, landing platforms for their LEGO ships, homes for the Barbies, etc.).

When our youngest daughter turned 2, I decided to bite the bullet on the price and purchase this 100 piece set for her Birthday. Sure, was young - but I knew these would be a long-living toy staple for both our kids. I also liked that we could add onto their set as time went on.

Boy, was I right. Our daughter (now 4), and our son (now 9) still play with these things almost everyday.

I have seen these things be everything - buildings, roads, stuck together and then 'cut' into pieces of food for the kitchen set, designs, 3D ships, a great wall of China around our poor sleeping dog, fortress walls, Nerf gun targets, doll houses, and the ever classic - 'how high can we make a tower before it breaks?!'.

Out of all the toys that they have, my husband and I joke that we know what items we'll hang onto for our future grand children... Magna-Tiles are one of the few. Seriously, they are timeless.

title: Magna-tiles

title: Best Toy Ever
text:
These building 'blocks' are seriously the best toy ever! I have three children ages 3, 5, and 7. ALL of them love Magna Tiles and play with them for hours-on-end. It's been over 6 months since we've had them and they still work with them every day.

The kids also include other toys as well, often putting figurines or animals inside their creations, making larger, more involved games.

YES, these are pretty expensive, but I would honestly say I've gotten more mileage out of Magna Tiles than any other toy we own. They are durable too, as they take lots of falling down and shuffling around.

GREAT as a gift idea! Wonderful for Grandma & Grandpa to have at their house.

text: I bought these Magna-Tiles for my grandchildren, a boy age 3 and a girl, age 7. The pieces don't get lost or broken and are simple to put away, because they are magnetic and stick together easily, so you can easily pick them up to put in a rather small box. title: Great toy, well worth the price
text:
My 2 boys (1 & 3 year olds) have enough toys to stock several departments at Toys R Us, yet this is the toy that (by far) gets used the most.

My older son enjoys building, and the younger one enjoys destroying; so, as long as we manage to keep the younger boy occupied long enough to allow the older one to complete his construction project, and then help the older brother channel his anger into re-building vs. hitting the young wrecking ball, we can have them occupied and delighted for long stretches of time. Therefore, despite the high price, I feel that this purchase has been a great value and recommend it to all of our friends with kids.

title: A gift for all ages, believe it or not!
text: Over a year ago, I paid what I thought was an exorbitant price for a 100 piece set for my two-year old grandson.  I had seen a friends Grandaughter do remarkable things with her set.  Since then I have doubled the purchase!  My daughter has two sons and is a nanny for two boys.  The range in age is 15 months to five years.  I have witnessed all four of the children sitting on the floor for up to 30 minutes at a time (yes even the 15 month old!) playing with the tiles.  Sometimes cooperatively and sometimes in parallel play.  The older children manage to build the most amazing 3D creations while the 15 month old builds one dimensional creations on the floor.  The key here is that the magnets are strong enough to stay together with little hands, while are strong enough to survive rough treatment.  Other, less expensive products cannot provide the durability of the Magna-tiles.  I will wholeheartedly recommend this product as an educational toy that delivers on engagement as well and brain-building challenges that will grow with your child.

title: Babysitting service - used over 4 yrs and STILL  has magnetic power!
text: I own a babysitting service called Napa Valley Nanny in Napa, CA.  I purchased the solid color set 4.5 yrs ago.  It's absolutely the most popular toy for girls and boys starting at 2.5 yrs....  Even the small triangles fascinate a 1 yr old (I bring 4-5, to show them how they stick)  Besides losing about 10 out of the 100 (not bad!) - I also keep each tile clean with a quick swipe of a sanitized rag, as I'm a fanatic about keeping my toys clean.  The tiles have been also thrown, stepped on, knocked over etc by various kids and these tiles are so well made - they aren't even phased by the abuse.  The best toy ever invented for the 3-6 yr age group - seriously!  But even some of the 7 yr olds will build cool stuff with these saying "I remember these when I was little"  hahaha!!

text:
We have owned these for two years now, and they continue to be played with regularly. My 13, 5 and 2 year olds all love to build with them. It cost me $200 (including shipping to Canada) to buy this set, but it has been worth it. The tiles are very durable, and there is no way for the magnets to come out, so safe as well.

Highly recommended!

title: I do NOT recommend leaving young children unattended with small pieces or magnetic ...
text:
[[VIDEOID:fb0ab63b1fdb85fcb4ea515e17401fc8]] Product: Magna-Tiles Clear Colors 100 Piece Set
Intent of Purpose: Education Tool (geometry, spatial concepts, sorting, etc.)
Duration of Use: 4 Months
Amount of Daily Use (low/moderate/high): Moderate
Age (range) of Primary User(s): Baby (10 month – 14 month)*, Adult
*As a fore note, I do NOT recommend leaving young children unattended with small pieces or magnetic toys. Seriously, don’t even look away or get up to go to the bathroom. Be responsible, please.

Durability / Longevity Rating: 5/5
My set has withstood moderate mistreatment from a toddler over the course of 4 months and still looks new. No pieces have broken. They have been frequently stepped on, chucked across the room, and dropped onto a tile floor.

Appearance /Presentation Rating: 5/5
Colorful and attractive. Not an eyesore.

Construction / Usefulness / Practicality Rating: 4/5
They are lightweight; I’d say no potential for broken windows, busted sheetrock, broken tile; not likely to result in severe injury and or concussion if they happen to become projectiles. The magnets rattle around when you shake an individual piece (not a negative quality).

Useful as an educational tool. Examples: construction; spatial concepts; geometry; multiple mathematical concepts; matching; stacking; etc.

The magnets are acceptable. Refer to my attached video; I have taken one Magformer and one Magna-Tile, each of similar size, placed them onto a magnetic baking tray, and demonstrated their staying power by tapping the tray against the floor. You can see that the Magformer generally stays put, while the Magna-Tile easily slides off.

I have found that, while it is possible to build tall/complex 3-D structures from these tiles, they generally work best as 2-D teaching aids (for me, anyhow). The magnets are not incredibly strong, but they do the job. 3D structures are easily collapsible. This shouldn’t dissuade you from trying these out; they are still a useful educational tool, but the easy collapsibility might be frustrating for younger users or those without steady hands.

Cost-Efficiency Rating (MSRP): 2/5
At the suggested retail price, this isn’t a cost-efficient item, and I haven’t seen this item go on sale yet.

Likeliness of Repurchase: Not likely, unless discounted.

Overall Rating: 4/5

text: My 8 year old and twin 6 year olds love the tiles!  They spend hours using their imagination to create structures ranging from rocket ships to hats to buildings for their stuffed animals.  My only problem is that I need more than one set!

title: Some assembly required...
text:
Some assembly required and that's a good thing. These are great fun and super easy to use. My son is 2.5 years and this is one of our favorite activities to do together. They are much easier to use than Legos and I am hoping to will be a great gateway into more sophisticated building toys. I highly recommend.

My only critical feedback is the cost and size of the set. 100 pieces is enough to build this tower that you see in this picture. It is enough to get started, but it is easy to get frustrated with wanting to have a few more pieces to build whatever you are working on. Don't shy away from doubling up in starter sets if you can swing the cost.

title: Wait until early 2012...
text:
These have seen a massive price hike because Valtech's production facilities have been shut down since October, due to flooding in Thailand. Magna Tiles are out of stock all over the place, so thanks to supply and demand these have gone from about $125 to $450. On their website it reads:

[Due to the recent historical flooding in Thailand, our production facilities have been closed since early October. We are temporarily out of all of our products. They will be available again early next year, along with some new additions. Our hearts go out to the people of Thailand for their suffering and hardship that have accompanied this natural disaster. Your interest and understanding is appreciated, and we hope to be of service to you soon. Keep an eye out for our new website also coming in the near future.]

That being said, my almost 5-year-old son has these in his pre-kindergarten classroom, and they are his (and many other students') favorite toy to play with. The possibilities are endless, and I can see a wide age range of kids enjoying building with them. Great for building, math, patterns, counting, geometry... the kids learn while they play and don't even know it! I'm sorry we won't be getting them in time for Christmas but I look forward to purchasing them after Valtech is up and running again.

text: Toys come and go, but the Magna-Tiles grow with your child, their skill, and their imagination. text: My 5 year old son played with some of these tiles at a family members house over Christmas and he couldn't stop talking about them!  He wanted them more than anything and so I had to get him some for Easter.  These tiles are super sturdy, heavy duty, with great coloring. title: Great playing and learning toy!

title: This Toy is a Keeper!
text:
I bought a 48 pc. set for my 3 year old five years ago. Since then we have purchased two more sets. My 8 year old still plays with them. At first, my children weren't sure how to use them, but I sat down to show them some basics and within five minutes they were busy building. The longer they have had them, the more things they learn to make with them. My 8 year old girl enjoys making shapes and all sorts of different objects. My 6 year old neice loves to build "houses" for her animals. My 5 year old son makes ramps, roadways and garages for his cars. All three of them do all sorts of other things with them; those are just some of their favorites --to give you an idea of the varied possibilities. Our 10 year old neighbor loves to play with them as well. This toy spans a large age group.
Magnatiles are very safe. I also have a smaller child, and I am not worried if any of the pieces get left out; they are too big to swallow and there are no sharp or unsafe pieces. Children love to build things and Magnatiles are an easy beginning for even the youngest builder. The magnets are strong enough to cling together well even if you get "close enough". I have had my tiles for five years, and I have never had one to break. They seem to be a sturdy, reliable, fun, educational toy.
I plan to keep mine even after my children out grow them. They are a great toy to have around for children of our guests. Since you can't just run down to Wal-Mart to buy this toy no one else I know has them, so when visitors come over they enjoy playing with this "new" toy. I recommend the clear ones; the children like to see the animals and cars that they have put inside. I also recommend the biggest set (110 pcs) because it is the best value, plus your children will be able to build bigger and better with more pieces. We started with a 48 pc. set and it was big enough for our young ones to build and play with. As they grew, so did their desire for more tiles to make more things!
As a note: I can never find these used on ebay, so people must not be getting rid of them! They love them, too, I guess.

title: fun for all ages, and a basis for math skills too!
text:
We first saw Magna-Tiles at the children's museum, and I immediately knew they'd be perfect for my sons, ages 5 and almost 3 years. We waited a couple of months for the older son's birthday to arrive before we purchased them, as the 100-piece set (which is really the minimum you need, especially for more than one "player") is around $130 by the time you pay postage. Due to the price, this was his only gift from us, but we thought that one gift was okay this year, as this toy sparks creativity and will begin to build math skills. Everyone in the family is enjoying these. Even my almost-three-year-old will spend 10-15 minutes at a time playing with them. The pieces seem very sturdy (the magnets are encased in plastic, so I am comfortable that there's not a risk of ingestion), but my boys throw them at times, so I will need to watch for cracking.

It would have been handy if they had come in a carrying case rather than just a cardboard box, but I bought a 15.5 liter Snapware container with lid and handle that holds them nicely, with room for growth in case we want to add to the collection someday.

I agree with previous reviewers that the translucent tiles are preferable to the opaque ones because they can be used with a light table (as at the museum), and the user can place little people or objects inside and still be able to see them.

I'm sure these will bring us years of enjoyment at different ages and stages. Great toy, and well worth the investment!

text: this item was recommended to me as i was waiting for a doctor's appointment. i needed a birthday gift for a two-year-old. a young woman raved about this item and so i went onto my go-to website, amazon.com and checked it out.  although it says for three years old and up, the pieces are big enough not to have to worry about my grandson swallowing them.  at $120 for the "value pack" of 100 pieces, it's a hefty price, but...all the kids from two years to seven years do not stop playing with them.  my four years old studies some pictures and then duplicates them to a tee. the girls build castles and they all build other things as well.  thanks to the young woman who said to buy this. oh, there are also enough pieces so that more than one child can build at the same time.

title: Fantastic

Blocks are durable (her brother loves to crash into her castles), have no little pieces that will break off, and magnets are strong enough that the structures hold together well.  It's one of those few , basic educational toys out there without buttons or noise.  (My kids now know that 2 triangles make a square, etc.)  It's worth buying the bigger package to avoid running out of tiles.

title: Great for 5 year old who likes to build and create
text:
My 5 year old received these as a gift one week ago and hasn't stopped playing with them, almost every chance he gets. He has created both large and small creations. I'm sorry we didn't get these for him sooner. We also debated which brand of magnetic tiles were the best choice and these were recommended by a museum worker to be the most durable and last the longest.
The price point is a bit high, but if your child has shown an interest in them in the past and you are also on the fence, I would say get them. The 100 piece count gives him lots to build with. The size of the pieces are very manageable, and the assorted colors are nice looking.
My son loves Legos and is good at following the original directions (still needing assistance at times) and does well at creating small things with his imagination. Magnatiles are a really excellent fit for him and he has been playing independently with them with no frustration and really getting creative.
The only downfall I can see so far is when he wants to show you what he's made, if it's a large creation he can't carry it to you. But I'm sure we'll get him a tray to build on to resolve that.

title: the best toy ever!
text: My 3 year old daughter LOVES these and can't get enough of them!  My husband and I also really enjoy playing with them - it's our go-to toy when we all play together.  They are very sturdy and totally safe.  The magnets are inside the tiles, so they can't come out.  We have an infant as well, so we were worried about having magnets around her.  The translucent colors are great because you can put things inside what you build and still see them.  I'm a geometry teacher, so obviously I love them and can create lots of cool shapes and polyhedra with the tiles.  My husband is an artist and he made a shark complete with a top fin - it really looked like a shark, too!  I can't say enough good things about this product.  I do recommend the 100 piece set because 32 pieces just isn't enough, especially if you have a bunch of kids that want to play with the tiles at the same time.  Well worth the money - your kids will get hours of educational play out of this!!

text:

It is perfect for imaginative play, developing gross and fine motor skills and spacial awareness, as well as individual and cooperative problem solving skills.

text:
I have a 4 year old son who is autistic. He has always played with Legos and Fisher Price Trio. I needed to find a new toy to be used as a reinforcer for therapy and to keep him busy during down time. This set was the perfect solution! My son creates patterns and builds towers. Clean up is so easy. The tiles' magnets snap together into piles in seconds, and you are out the door. It is almost impossible to lose them!
I understand that the price is on the high end (@ $1.20 per tile), but, I just ordered my 2nd set of 100. They are soooo worth it!

text:
The daycare that our kids attended has a few sets of these tiles for the 2 year old + group. The kids love them, and our son was playing with them as often as he could. We bought them for him for Christmas right after his 3rd birthday and it is one of the few toys that still gets his daily attention. (matchbox cars is the other) These tiles are a bit pricey, but they are durable and you get quite a few of all sizes.
After months of use, including by our 1 year old who is known to throw things, we have not had a single broken tile. Our son builds his 'towers' then crashes them down!!
Our 1 year old messes with the tiles, but I would say that 2 years or older is good age range.
We will be purchasing additional kits for b-days or other occasions.
Dad even plays with these from time to time, I build little obstacles courses for my mini RC crawler!!

If you have a child that seems to like puzzles, tools, shapes, magnets, etc this would be a great fit....

text: I purchased a set of these for my daughters' preschool classroom and they are truly loved. title: Great educational toy
text:
It took me a long time to find a toy my kids (5 and 19 months) can both enjoy. They received this as a Christmas present. It is by far the most-played present they received this year and is well-worth the price. They seem quite durable. My 19-month old has been stepping on them (yikes!) but they haven't cracked. She seems to just do 2D shapes for now unlike her 5-year old sister who has been making 3D objects. Nice toy to introduce geometry.

Even at a 100 pieces it seems like they can use more, if they have to share. For the most part it has worked out very well. This clear version is certainly very nice. You can put little objects inside when building boxes, houses, etc.

It also stacks away neatly since they all just stick to each other in one big pile. I don't have to worry about a 100 pieces scattering all over the place when it's time to clean up.

I highly recommend this toy.

title: Encourages creativity
text:
I have a tale to tell.

Several years ago, it seemed any package or letter that the carrier couldn't find was just delivered to us. Usually I managed to get it to the right place. There are two notable exceptions. One, a W-2 with my husband's (very common) name addressed to an address that didnt exist for a company not in our state, much less that he'd worked for. I tried on that. I googled variations of the address, contacted peeple with the name on Facebook. Google was odd. No matter what variation of the address I googled, I always found a guy in a blue GMC with wooden slats in place of the tailgate wearing a white hat. But I never did get that W-2 to the right person, even after calling the business and letting them know.

Second was around Christmas, once of many packages left on our door but not for us and the only one I couldn't locate the right person. Name didn't exist on Google or social media and address didn't exist at all. FedEx said they'd come get it to properly deliver it, but never did. After several weeks, I opened it. Thus finding my son's favorite new toy.

It was with these tiles that I realized my autistic son is a math genius. I got him more and he still loves them, five years later as he's about to turn 7. He loves to build and can tell you how many tiles he needs for his design before he's started. I just love how creative he gets. Honestly, this accidental gift from Fed-ex is the first thing that ever truly engaged him.

title: Five Stars

title: Perfect for Building with Toddlers!
text:
Without hesitation I can easily rate Magna-Tiles a perfect five stars! My three year old son and I were first introduced to them through his daycare provider. I began to realize they were his toy of choice as I read his take home slips and saw his excitement in showing them to me at pickup each day. They were all he seemed to talk about!

Santa Claus brought this set to our home for Christmas this year. It was non-stop play for days! The magnetic sides make construction easier for young builders as the tiles "snap" into place. Building requires a little less perfection than Legos or other traditional building blocks. I enjoy building with my son and seeing his enthusiasm for making new things and taking them apart.

I definitely recommend the 100 piece set versus the others with fewer tiles. We use the majority of tiles each time we build. I'd worry a smaller set would be too limiting. We really like the see-through material of this set versus the opaque option. Both build the same of course.

My son is nearly four, and I can honestly say this is the best toy I've purchased for him out of everything we've ever gotten! The cost is clearly high compared to a normal toy purchase you might make, but it is more than worth it! We love Magna Tiles so much, my mom even picked up a set for her house for all the grandkids and visitors. We love this toy!

title: Worth the money
text:
My wife bought these for our son after playing with them at the local children's museum. I was shocked at the price, it's over $1 / piece but we play with them every day. My wife's been joking that she should waited until Father's day to get them because my son and I spend so much time with them.

They fit together firmly enough that we've made some very tall towers and are durable enough to withstand my 40lb son stepping on them.

The only thing I would change is more right angle pieces and fewer of the tall triangles. The other two triangles can be used to make various slopes but the taller triangles can't be combined into a useful angle. They usually end up as decoration more than a key part of the structures.

title: 9 Year review
text:
First bought these back in 2013. These magna tiles have gone through 3 kids with the third being 1 and half yrs old now. I've noticed that at that age they just like to destroy whatever you make, but that's okay. As they get older in the 2s and 3s they start building simple stuff and you can wow them with complicated combinations. The magnets aren't super strong, but they are strong enough where it will hold together without snapping together and pinching anyone's fingers. For me the funnest part of using these is finding ways to incorporate them into other toys. Like making a garage for hot wheels, creating tunnels and cities for your duplo train to pass through, or creating space ships for your lego Buz Lightyear to cruise around in. I happened to make a light table out of a cheap ikea table as well and it's cool to just set these on it and build and watch your structure illuminate.

After 9 years I can only recall maybe two pieces cracking or breaking and that was only after my oldest at the time (maybe 7 or 8) had a friend over who was rough with the magna tiles. Outside of those two the only issue I've had with these is they get scuffed up over time and you lose one or two every now and then. Never had a magnet fall out.

title: Most amazing toy I ever bought!
text: My nine-year-old son loves these magnetic tiles. I like them because he can build what ever is on his mind. He also can make things faster and bigger then legos and they don’t hurt if you step on them. When I first got them I thought that they were too expensive for what you get, but I tried them out and he had so much fun with them. We have bought him five sets and he has 500 magnetic tiles. You need at least 300 to be able to make really cool things. I also like that these tiles are educational in a fun way. You learn to make buildings and how to support the roof. The tallest building he has made yet out of magnetic tiles was 7.6 feet! He had to get the kitchen stool and I never thought he would make something that big. These are great Christmas and birthday presents. And kids and adults of all ages can use them. They are great for using when you have a friend over to construct with both ideas. I like the see-though kind better than the non see-through kind because it looks like stained glass. If you get the 100 set there are 4 large squares, 50 small squares, 20 equilateral triangles, 15 isosceles triangles and 11 right triangles so in total you have 100 pieces. These are truly the best toys ever!

title: Best toy purchase EVER!!!
text: This was a Christmas present last year for my two sons (5 & 2). The magna tiles have been played with nearly every single day for an entire year!! They are, in fact, constructed on my coffee table at this very moment! I babysit approximately 10 other kids ages 1-10 & this is the toy they all scramble to get to first! I'm quite impressed with the variety of things the kids have built - even the 2 yr old! This is certainly a toy for all ages, for I've found my self at times drawn to build something creative! This toy has been so popular in my home that I've decided to get the boys two more hundred piece sets for Christmas, regardless of the price! Hoping this will solve the "I ran out of tiles" problem. More is better with this toy! Don't bother getting the smaller set because you'll wish you had more once you get them & will most likely end up buying more sets anyways!

title: The best purchase ever !
text: I run a small daycare in my home.  My students are 18 months to 5 years.  All of them love these colorful magnetic tiles.  They are sturdy and have strong magnets that easily go together and stay together.  We have used them on the light table, used them in combination with flash lights, and against a door-wall to create a stained glass window.  I allow two children to play at a time so that each has plenty of tiles.  The younger children make flat, one dimensional shapes and as they gain in age and ability, they create large three dimensional, multi-level structures.  This is by far, the best purchase ever !

title: The very best!
text:
I bought this set two years ago when my children were 3 and 5, and I remember worrying that maybe they were on the old side for these and would soon outgrow them. I went ahead and bought them anyway, and I'm so glad, because they continue to play with them every day, while the other toys languish on the shelves. They can create so many elaborate inventions with Magna Tiles -- they're always inventing something new.

The price may not be cheap, but if you think of all the hours and hours your kids will spend with their Magna Tiles, it's well worth it.

title: Great gift for a preschooler!
text: I ordered the Magna-Tiles 100 piece set as a birthday gift for my 4 year old son. When the package arrived, I was skeptical because the box was much smaller than I expected. However, once we opened the box, we found that this is the perfect size. 100 pieces are plenty for a child to build any number of structures. I'm impressed with the quality so far. This is one of my son's favorite toys at the moment! (And mine too.)

title: Great investment!
text: After years of buying expensive toys that lose their novelty with my children very quickly, this one has stood the test of time.  I first saw Magna Tiles at a children's museum, where all of the children were clamoring to use them.  Since buying them myself, all three of my children (ages 2-7) use them at length every day.  The tiles are so versatile that my children incorporate them into almost every other game they play.  I was hesitant to pay so much for the 100-tile set, but now I'm tempted to buy another one!

title: Magnatiles online information missing
text: My 3 stars are only meant to indicate that the ad for this product, 100 piece box of Magnatiles, does not have sufficient information for the buyer.  It is an expensive item, and yes, it does have 100 pieces, but only 54 of the pieces are the kind of squares most useful for building structures.  The rest are various shaped triangles, much less useful, especially for young children. Since the buyer has no way of knowing this information, or knowing the sizes of the pieces, it is a risky purchase.  Magnatiles are a GREAT toy, but they are expensive and the purchaser should know up front what types of pieces and their sizes are inside. This is one great weakness of buying toys on amazon.com

title: Best building tiles for preschoolers!
text: Over the past 3 years I have purchased 5 sets (the one hundred piece sets) for classrooms in my preschool facilities.  The children love using their imaginations to build with these beautiful colorful tiles.  These high quality tiles are extremely durable and able to take all the abuse our preschoolers give them.  Because the tiles contain small magnets I was concerned about child safety. I liked the fact that all magnets are sealed inside the tiles and the tiles are closed with rivets. Before buying Magna-Tiles I researched other brands and saw that the magnets were not secure enough to prevent possible removal by a child and were a swallowing hazard.  Manga-Tiles are a better bang for your buck than the less expensive brand tiles because they are safer and more durable than other brands.  I have another set of these in my cart for a gift to my little grandson!  He’s going to love them!

title: Fun for all ages

title: Boost a child's creativity and language development
text: I admit that the set was pricey, but I have watched my four-year-old nephew play with his set over skype and thought that the money I spent was really worth it. Every attempt to build something is a new adventure and when he is explaining to us what he is building, we have the opportunity to teach him new vocabulary in three languages (we are a trilingual family). The he practices all of his languages by describing his creation to others!

title: Better buy at least the 100 pieces in translucent
text: I bought the 100 piece set for my grandkids last Christmas thinking that it was a lot of money for a toy.  I am back this year to buy two more sets for the same grandkids. They play with them every day.  A great toy for supporting imagination, creativity and spatial cognitive abilities.  I have been there when the five-year-old has built rockets, a machine that eats garbage (the triangles served as teeth), while the 2+ year-old builds boxes for matchbox cars, tunnels, rockets etc etc etc.  Their mom requested more sets because each builds his own contraptions. Another benefit: when they are done the tiles fit back into a small space. I just saw the price...usually amazon has it for around $100 to $110.

text:
Too expensive but my kids adore these! These are great for beginner builders. Both of my children love this toy (ages 5 & 8). But I see them for sale everywhere. title: Best toy in the house
text:
We had the 30 piece set already and the kids absolutely loved them so we got them more. They (and I) love these blocks. Just like everyone else has said in their reviews, these blocks will take a beating and more. Our blocks have lasted through falling down the stairs, being thrown onto the hard wood floor, tossed around outside, kicked, jumped on, smashed, bathed, etc.

They are expensive for what you get, but well worth the price. My son loves coming up with new designs and I love trying to defy gravity with my designs. They stick to the refrigerator and the bath tub which is fun with the kids.

I highly recommend these for kids of all ages.

title: Can't have enough of these
text: We have 1 large set and 1 small set shared by 3 boys ages 4 to 6. We have had them over 2 years, and they are by far the favorite, for my boys and their friends that come over. They started out making buildings, and now  create spacecraft. boats, launches, docks, etc. They make boxes and "wrap" toys in them for gifts for momma. I really see these as the modern day wooden block, with magnets and great colors.  And unlike legos, there is building without millions of tiny pieces that can get lost. And you really can't have enough. I think we will add to the collection this Christmas and get another large set. $150 is expensive, but if you think of all the junk out there with little pieces that break of get lost, and the creative value it gives children, it somehow seems worth it. My boys play and imagine for hours. Can't put a price on that.

title: BEST TOY EVER FOR GRANDMA'S HOUSE
text: These are FABULOUS.  I bought them for my grandchildren to use when they come to visit.  My 3, 4, 5 and 7 year old grandsons play with them for hours every time they come.  The 7 year old builds tall towers, castles, forts, parking garages and whatever else he decides.  The 4 and 5 year olds build more simple structures.  Garages to house their cars are the most popular.  The 3 year old uses the tiles to make flat structures.  Pizzas using the large triangles are his favorite.  I originally bought the 100 piece set but added the 32 piece set so my 7 year old could build more complicated structures.  He uses almost all 132 tiles on occasions.  I take them to my 3 year old class at church for playtime on Sundays.  I notice that the boys love to play with them.  The girls will sometimes join in with the boys, but they don't like them as much as the boys.  My 4 and 11 year old granddaughters also do not play with them as much as the boys.

title: 4 large squares now included in the 100 piece set
text:
We bought our 100-piece set in September, and four large squares were included. There is a review that says no large squares are included in the 100-piece set - that review is outdated.

Specifically, the set includes:
50 - 3"x3" Squares
15 - Isosceles Triangles
11 - Right Triangles
20 - Equilateral Triangles
4 - 6x6 triangles

We've had magnatiles for approximately two months now, and my daughter has played with them every day. Magna-tiles are very open-ended and can be incorporated into practically any game. Rocket ships. Parking garages for matchbox cars. Jail cells and homes for little people and weebles. My daughter constantly amazes me by what she builds.

As a parent, I really love magnatiles too. I can see educational opportunities in them from preschool to geometry. Right off, my daughter learned that two right-triangles make a square, three isosceles triangles make a trapezoid. She instantly figured out how to build cubes and pyramids and she said, "I'm a cube builder! I'm a pyramid builder!" In addition, I use magnatiles to teach about patterns.

We have both translucent and opaque magnatiles. At times, my daughter will yank the opaque ones away from me and give me a translucent one instead. That way she can see her weebles and little people inside of her structures. So if you're choosing between the two, I'd buy translucent.

So, in conclusion, buy the translucent magnatiles! This is the best toy ever!!

title: Worth the price

title: Best toy for kids, hands down.
text: Were these a bit expensive? Yes, but looking at the amount of time my son has spent playing with these compared to the amount of time he has spent playing with other toys, there is just no comparison.  Endless opportunities for creativity, the magnets are strong and everything stores neatly.  We are adding more to his wish list because he wants his castles to be "BIGGER!".

title: Performed a Rough Magnet Strength Comparison to MagBlock, Magna Tiles Lost
text:
I read a couple reviews saying Magna Tiles were the ones to get; then came here and saw a number of reviews that said the Magna Tile magnets were not as strong. (Some reviewers mentioned that they used to be stronger.) It annoyed me that the professional reviews and the customer reviews didn't match, so I purchased a small set of each and performed a "paperclip comparison" by hanging identical paperclips to each brand.
https://smile.amazon.com/dp/B01HFH5Q8G?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2_dt_b_product_details
https://smile.amazon.com/dp/B07HJ1767D?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2_dt_b_product_details

The Magna Tile held 30 clips, the Mag Block help 37 clips, so the Mag Block was about 23% stronger.
I confess that I did not try multiple magnets and average them out, but since the Mag Block magnet even looked slightly bigger I figured the experiment could end.

The Magna Tiles were still very nice, so I gave them 4 stars; but when I purchased a large set I went with the Mag Blocks.
